Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: Canadian Electrical Code means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard C22.1-1990, Canadian Electrical Code, Part I, dated January 1990, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard C22.3 No.1-M1979, Overhead Systems and Underground Systems, dated April, 1979; (Code canadien de l’électricité)

Definition.Text: control device means a device that will safely disconnect electrical equipment from its source of energy; (dispositif de commande)
electrical equipment means equipment for the generation, distribution or use of electricity; (outillage électrique)
guarantor means a person who gives a guarantee of isolation; (garant)

guarded means covered, shielded, fenced, enclosed or otherwise protected by means of suitable covers or casings, barriers, guardrails, screens, mats or platforms to remove the possibility of dangerous contact or approach by persons or objects; (protégé)
isolated means separated or disconnected from every source of electrical, hydraulic, pneumatic or other kind of energy that is capable of making electrical equipment dangerous; (isolé)
person in charge means an employee who supervises employees performing work on or a live test of isolated electrical equipment. (responsable)

Section.Text: This Part does not apply to the underground workings of mines.

Subsection.Text: The design, construction and installation of all electrical equipment shall meet the standards set out in the Canadian Electrical Code, Part I, in so far as is reasonably practicable.
The operation and maintenance of all electrical equipment shall meet the standards set out in the Canadian Electrical Code.
All testing or work performed on electrical equipment shall be performed by a qualified person or an employee under the direct supervision of a qualified person.
Where the electrical equipment has a voltage in excess of 5,200 V between any two conductors or in excess of 3,000 V between any conductor and ground,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the qualified person or the employee referred to in subsection (1) shall use such insulated protection equipment and tools as will protect him from injury during the performance of the work; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employee referred to in subsection (1) shall be instructed and trained in the use of the insulated protection equipment and tools.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), no employee shall work on electrical equipment unless the equipment is isolated.

If it is not reasonably practicable to isolate the electrical equipment and an employee must work on live equipment, the employer shall instruct the employee in procedures that are safe for live conductors.
Where electrical equipment is not live but is capable of becoming live, no employee shall work on the equipment unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: procedures that are safe for work on live equipment are used; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a safety ground is connected to the equipment.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsections (5) and (6), where an employee is working on or near electrical equipment that is live or may become live, the electrical equipment shall be guarded.

Subject to subsection (6), where it is not practicable for the electrical equipment referred to in subsection (4) to be guarded, the employer shall take measures to protect the employee from injury by insulating the equipment from the employee or the employee from ground.

Where live electrical equipment is not guarded or insulated in accordance with subsection (4) or (5) or where the employee referred to in subsection (5) is not insulated from ground, the employee shall not work so near to any live part of the electrical equipment that is within a voltage range listed in column I of an item of the schedule to this Part that the distance between the body of the employee or any thing with which the employee is in contact and the live part of the equipment is less than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the distance set out in column II of that item, where the employee is not a qualified person; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the distance set out in column III of that item, where the employee is a qualified person.

Subsection.Text: No employee shall work near a live part of any electrical equipment referred to in subsection (6) where there is a hazard that an unintentional movement by the employee would bring any part of the body of the employee or any thing with which the employee is in contact closer to that live part than the distance referred to in that subsection.

Section.Text: No employee shall work on or near high voltage electrical equipment unless he is authorized to do so by his employer.

A legible sign with the words “Danger — High Voltage” and “Danger — Haute Tension” in letters that are not less than 50 mm in height on a contrasting background shall be posted in a conspicuous place at every approach to live high voltage electrical equipment.

Subsection.Text: Where an employee is working on or near live electrical equipment and, because of the nature of the work or the condition or location of the work place, it is necessary for the safety of the employee that the work be observed by a person not engaged in the work, the employer shall appoint a safety watcher

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to warn all employees in the work place of the hazard; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to ensure that all safety precautions and procedures are complied with.

Subsection.Text: A safety watcher shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: informed of his duties as a safety watcher and of the hazard involved in the work;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: trained and instructed in the procedures to follow in the event of an emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: authorized to stop immediately any part of the work that he considers dangerous; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: free of any other duties that might interfere with his duties as a safety watcher.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), an employer may appoint himself as a safety watcher.

Section.Text: Where an employee is working on or in connection with electrical equipment, that employee and every other person who is so working, including every safety watcher, shall be fully informed by the employer with respect to the safe coordination of their work.

Subsection.Text: Before an employee climbs a pole or elevated structure that is used to support electrical equipment, the employer shall give instructions and training to the employee respecting inspections and tests of the pole or structure to be carried out before the pole or structure is climbed.

Where, as a result of an inspection or test of a pole or elevated structure referred to in subsection (1), it appears to an employee that the pole or structure will be safe for climbing only when temporary supports have been installed, pike-poles alone shall not be used for such supports.

No employee shall work on any pole or elevated structure referred to in subsection (1) unless he has been instructed and trained in the rescue of employees who may be injured in the course of the work.

Section.Text: Every pole or elevated structure that is embedded in the ground and is used to support electrical equipment shall meet the standards set out in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard CAN3-015-M83, Wood Utility Poles and Reinforcing Studs, dated January, 1983; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard A14-M1979, Concrete Poles, the English version of which is dated September 1979 and the French version of which is dated November 1987.

Subsection.Text: Before an employee isolates electrical equipment or changes or terminates the isolation of electrical equipment, the employer shall issue written instructions with respect to the procedures to be followed for the safe performance of that work.
The instructions referred to in subsection (1) shall be signed by the employer and shall specify

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the instructions are issued;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour of the commencement and of the termination of the period during which the instructions are to be followed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the employee to whom the instructions are issued; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the instructions are in respect of the operation of a control device that affects the isolation of the electrical equipment,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the device to which the instructions apply, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where applicable, the correct sequence of procedures.

Subsection.Text: A copy of the instructions referred to in subsection (1) shall be shown and explained to the employee.

The instructions referred to in subsection (1) shall be kept readily available for examination by employees for the period referred to in paragraph (2)(b) and thereafter shall be kept by the employer for a period of one year at his place of business nearest to the work place in which the electrical equipment is located.
Subject to subsection (4), no work on or live test of isolated electrical equipment shall be performed unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: isolation of the equipment has been confirmed by test; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employer has determined, on the basis of visual observation, that every control device and every locking device necessary to establish and maintain the isolation of the equipment

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is set in the safe position with the disconnecting contacts of control devices safely separated or, in the case of a draw-out type electrical switch gear, is withdrawn to its full extent from the contacts of the electrical switch gear,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is locked out, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: bears a distinctive tag or sign designed to notify persons that operation of the control device and movement of the locking device are prohibited during the performance of the work or live test.

Subsection.Text: Where more than one employee is performing any work on or live test of isolated electrical equipment, a separate tag or sign for each such employee shall be attached to each control device and locking device referred to in subsection (1).
The tag or sign referred to in subparagraph (1)(b)(iii) or subsection (2) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contain the words “DO NOT OPERATE — DÉFENSE D’ACTIONNER” or display a symbol conveying the same meaning;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: show the date and hour that the control device and the locking device referred to in paragraph (1)(b) were set in the safe position or were withdrawn to their full extent from the contacts;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: show the name of the employee performing the work or live test;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where used in connection with a live test, be distinctively marked as a testing tag or sign;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: be removed only by the employee performing the work or live test; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: be used for no purpose other than the purpose referred to in paragraph (1)(b)(iii).

Subsection.Text: Where, because of the nature of the work in which the electrical equipment is being used, it is not practicable to comply with subsection (1), no work on or live test of electrical equipment shall be performed unless a guarantee of isolation referred to in section 8.14 is given to the person in charge.

Heading.TitleText: Guarantees of Isolation for Electrical Equipment

Subsection.Text: No employee shall give or receive a guarantee of isolation for electrical equipment unless he is authorized in writing by his employer to give or receive a guarantee of isolation.
Not more than one employee shall give a guarantee of isolation for a piece of electrical equipment for the same period of time.
Before an employee performs work on or a live test of isolated electrical equipment, the person in charge shall receive from the guarantor

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a written guarantee of isolation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where owing to an emergency it is not practicable for the person in charge to receive a written guarantee of isolation, a non-written guarantee of isolation.

Subsection.Text: A written guarantee of isolation referred to in paragraph (3)(a) shall be signed by the guarantor and by the person in charge and shall contain the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the guarantee of isolation is given to the person in charge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the electrical equipment will become isolated;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the isolation will be terminated, if known;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures by which isolation is assured;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the guarantor and the person in charge; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a statement as to whether live tests are to be performed.

Subsection.Text: Where a non-written guarantee of isolation referred to in paragraph (3)(b) is given, a written record thereof shall forthwith

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be made by the guarantor; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be made and signed by the person in charge.

Subsection.Text: A written record referred to in subsection (5) shall contain the information referred to in subsection (4).
Every written guarantee of isolation and every written record referred to in subsection (5) shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: kept by the person in charge readily available for examination by the employee performing the work or live test until the work or live test is completed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: given to the employer when the work or live test is completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: kept by the employer for a period of one year after the completion of the work or live test at his place of business nearest to the work place in which the electrical equipment is located.

Section.Text: Where a written guarantee of isolation or a written record of an oral guarantee of isolation is given to a person in charge and the person in charge is replaced at the work place by another person in charge before the guarantee has terminated, the other person in charge shall sign the written guarantee of isolation or written record of the oral guarantee of isolation.

Before an employee gives a guarantee of isolation for electrical equipment that obtains all or any portion of its electrical energy from a source that is not under his direct control, the employee shall obtain a guarantee of isolation in respect of the source from the person who is in direct control thereof and is authorized to give the guarantee in respect thereof.

Subsection.Text: No employee shall give a guarantee of isolation for the performance of a live test on isolated electrical equipment unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any other guarantee of isolation given in respect of the electrical equipment for any part of the period for which the guarantee of isolation is given is terminated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: every person to whom the other guarantee of isolation referred to in paragraph (a) was given has been informed of its termination; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any live test to be performed on the electrical equipment will not be hazardous to the health or safety of the person performing the live test.

Subsection.Text: Every person performing a live test shall warn all persons who, during or as a result of the test, are likely to be exposed to a hazard.
Every person in charge shall, when work on or a live test of isolated electrical equipment is completed,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: inform the guarantor thereof; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make and sign a record in writing containing the date and hour when he so informed the guarantor and the name of the guarantor.

Subsection.Text: On receipt of the information referred to in subsection (1), the guarantor shall make and sign a record in writing containing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date and hour when the work or live test was completed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person in charge.

Subsection.Text: The records referred to in subsections (1) and (2) shall be kept by the employer for a period of one year after the date of signature thereof at his place of business nearest to the work place in which the electrical equipment is located.
No employee shall attach a safety ground to electrical equipment unless he has tested the electrical equipment and has established that it is isolated.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of electrical equipment that is grounded by means of a grounding switch that is an integral part of the equipment.
Subject to subsection (2), no work shall be performed on any electrical equipment in an area in which is located

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a grounding bus,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a station grounding network,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a neutral conductor,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: temporary phase grounding, or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a metal structure

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: unless the equipment referred to in paragraphs (a) to (e) is connected to a common grounding network.

Subsection.Text: Where, after the connections referred to in subsection (1) are made, a safety ground is required to ensure the safety of an employee working on the electrical equipment referred to in that subsection, the safety ground shall be connected to the common grounding network.

Section.Text: Every conducting part of a safety ground on isolated electrical equipment shall have sufficient current carrying capacity to conduct the maximum current that is likely to be carried on any part of the equipment for such time as is necessary to permit operation of any device that is installed on the electrical equipment so that, in the event of a short circuit or other electrical current overload, the electrical equipment is automatically disconnected from its source of electrical energy.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2), a

Definition.Text: point of safety grounding means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a grounding bus, a station grounding network, a neutral conductor, a metal structure or an aerial ground, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one or more metal rods that are not less than 16 mm in diameter and are driven not less than l m into undisturbed compact earth at a minimum distance of 4.5 m from the base of the pole, structure, apparatus or other thing to which the electrical equipment is attached or from the area where persons on the ground work and in a direction away from the main work area. (point de mise à la terre)

Subsection.Text: No safety ground shall be attached to or disconnected from isolated electrical equipment except in accordance with the following requirements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground shall, to the extent that is practicable, be attached to the pole, structure, apparatus or other thing to which the electrical equipment is attached;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all isolated conductors, neutral conductors and all non-insulated surfaces of the electrical equipment shall be short-circuited, electrically bonded together and attached by a safety ground to a point of safety grounding in a manner that establishes equal voltage on all surfaces that can be touched by persons who work on the electrical equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground shall be attached by means of mechanical clamps that are tightened securely and are in direct contact with bare metal;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground shall be so secured that none of its parts can make contact accidentally with any live electrical equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground shall be attached and disconnected using insulated protection equipment and tools;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground shall, before it is attached to isolated electrical equipment, be attached to a point of safety grounding; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the safety ground shall, before being disconnected from the point of safety grounding, be removed from the isolated electrical equipment in such a manner that the employee avoids contact with all live conductors.

Subsection.Text: Every control device shall be so designed and located as to permit quick and safe operation at all times.
The path of access to every electrical switch, control device or meter shall be free from obstruction.

Where an electrical switch or other device controlling the supply of electrical energy to electrical equipment is operated only by a person authorized to do so by the employer, the switch or other device shall be fitted with a locking device that only an authorized person can activate.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: ARI means the Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration Institute of the United States; (ARI)
Canadian Plumbing Code means the Canadian Plumbing Code, 1985; (Code canadien de la plomberie)
field accommodation means fixed or mobile accommodation that is living, eating or sleeping quarters provided by an employer for the accommodation of employees at a work place; (logement sur place)
mobile accommodation means field accommodation that may be easily and quickly moved. (logement mobile)

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall maintain each personal service room and food preparation area used by employees in a clean and sanitary condition.
Personal service rooms and food preparation areas shall be so used by employees that the rooms or areas will remain as clean and in such a sanitary condition as is possible.

Section.Text: All janitorial work that may cause dusty or unsanitary conditions shall be carried out in a manner that will prevent the contamination of the air by dust or other substances injurious to health.
Each personal service room shall be cleaned at least once every day that it is used.

Subsection.Text: Every plumbing system that supplies potable water and removes water-borne waste

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall meet the standards set out in the Canadian Plumbing Code; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), shall be connected to a municipal sanitation sewer or water main.

Subsection.Text: Where it is not practicable to comply with paragraph (1)(b), the employer shall provide a waste disposal system that meets the standards set out in ANSI standard ANSI Z4.3-1979, Minimum Requirements for Nonsewered Waste-Disposal Systems, dated November 8, 1978.
Each container that is used for solid or liquid waste in the work place shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be equipped with a tight-fitting cover;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be so constructed that it can easily be cleaned and maintained in a sanitary condition;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be leak-proof; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where there may be internal pressure in the container, be so designed that the pressure is relieved by controlled ventilation.

Subsection.Text: Each container referred to in subsection (1) shall be emptied at least once every day that it is used.
Each enclosed part of a work place, each personal service room and each food preparation area shall be constructed, equipped and maintained in a manner that will prevent the entrance of vermin.

Where vermin have entered any enclosed part of a work place, personal service room or food preparation area, the employer shall immediately take all steps necessary to eliminate the vermin and prevent the re-entry of the vermin.

Section.Text: No person shall use a personal service room for the purpose of storing equipment unless a closet fitted with a door is provided in that room for that purpose.

In each personal service room and food preparation area, the temperature, measured one metre above the floor in the centre of the room or area, shall be maintained at a level of not less than 18°C and, where reasonably practicable, not more than 29°C.

Subsection.Text: In each personal service room and food preparation area, the floors, partitions and walls shall be so constructed that they can be easily washed and maintained in a sanitary condition.
The floor and lower 150 mm of any walls and partitions in any food preparation area or toilet room shall be water-tight and impervious to moisture.

Section.Text: Where separate personal service rooms are provided for employees of each sex, each room shall be equipped with a door that is self-closing and is clearly marked to indicate the sex of the employees for whom the room is provided.

Subsection.Text: Where it is reasonably practicable, a toilet room shall be provided for employees and, subject to section 9.13, where persons of both sexes are employed at the same work place, a separate toilet room shall be provided for employees of each sex.

Subject to subsections (3) and (4), where a toilet room is provided in accordance with subsection (1), the employer shall provide in that room a number of toilets determined according to the maximum number of employees of each sex who are normally employed by him at any one time at the same work place as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of such employees does not exceed nine, one toilet;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of such employees exceeds nine but does not exceed 24, two toilets;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of such employees exceeds 24 but does not exceed 49, three toilets;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of such employees exceeds 49 but does not exceed 74, four toilets;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of such employees exceeds 74 but does not exceed 100, five toilets; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of such employees exceeds 100, five toilets and one toilet for every 30 such employees or portion of that number in excess of 100.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (4), where the class of employment in a work place is the transaction of business or the rendering of professional or personal services, the number of toilets provided by the employer in accordance with subsection (2) may be reduced

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of employees of each sex does not exceed 25, to one toilet;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of employees of each sex exceeds 25 but does not exceed 50, to two toilets; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of employees of each sex exceeds 50, to three toilets and one toilet for every 50 employees or portion of that number in excess of 50.

Subsection.Text: An employer may substitute urinals for up to two-thirds of the number of toilets required by subsection (2) or (3) to be provided for male employees.

For the purposes of subsections (2) and (3), an employee who is normally away from his work place for more than 75 per cent of his working time and does not normally use the toilet room in the work place shall not be counted.
Where reasonably practicable, toilet rooms and wash basins separate from those used by other employees shall be provided for food handlers.
Subject to subsection (2), an employer may provide only one toilet for both male and female employees if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the total number of employees normally employed by him in the work place at any one time does not exceed five; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the door of the toilet room is fitted on the inside with a locking device.

Subsection.Text: Where the class of employment in a work place is the transaction of business or the rendering of professional or personal services, the employer may provide only one toilet for both male and female employees if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the total number of employees normally employed by him in the work place at any one time does not exceed 10 or the area of the work place does not exceed 100 m2; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the door of the toilet room is fitted on the inside with a locking device.

Section.Text: Toilet rooms shall be located not more than 60 m from and not more than one storey above or below each work place.
Every toilet room shall be so designed that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is completely enclosed with solid material that is non-transparent from the outside;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: no toilet or urinal is visible when the door of the toilet room is open;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it has a ceiling height of not less than 2.2 m;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the toilet room contains more than one toilet, each toilet is enclosed in a separate compartment fitted with a door and an inside locking device; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the walls of each separate toilet compartment are designed and constructed to provide a reasonable amount of privacy for its occupant.

Section.Text: Toilet paper on a holder or in a dispenser shall be provided

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where there is only one toilet in a toilet room, in that toilet room; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in each toilet compartment.

Section.Text: A covered container for the disposal of sanitary napkins shall be provided in each toilet room provided for the use of female employees.
Hot water provided for personal washing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be maintained at a temperature of not less than 35°C and not more than 43°C; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall not be heated by mixing with steam.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 9.20 and 9.21, every employer shall provide for each toilet room wash basins supplied with cold water and hot water that meets the requirements of section 9.18 as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the room contains one or two toilets or urinals, one wash basin; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the room contains more than two toilets or urinals, one wash basin for every two toilets or urinals.

Subsection.Text: Where an outdoor privy is provided by an employer, the employer shall provide wash basins required by subsection (1) as close to the outdoor privy as is reasonably practicable.

Section.Text: Subject to section 9.21, where a toilet room is provided and the work environment of employees is such that their health is likely to be endangered by a hazardous substance coming into contact with their skin, the employer shall provide a wash room with individual wash basins supplied with cold water and hot water that meets the requirements of section 9.18 as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of those employees does not exceed five, one wash basin;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of those employees exceeds five but does not exceed 10, two wash basins;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of those employees exceeds 10 but does not exceed 15, three wash basins;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of those employees exceeds 15 but does not exceed 20, four wash basins; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: where the number of those employees exceeds 20, four wash basins and one additional wash basin for every 15 of those employees or portion of that number in excess of 20.

Subsection.Text: An industrial wash trough or circular wash basin of a capacity equivalent to the aggregate of the minimum standard capacities of the wash basins referred to in sections 9.19 and 9.20 may be provided in place of the wash basins.
An industrial wash trough or circular wash basin referred to in subsection (1) shall be supplied with cold water and hot water that meets the requirements of section 9.18.

Section.Text: In every personal service room that contains a wash basin, the employer shall provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: powdered or liquid soap or other cleaning agent in a dispenser at each wash basin or between adjoining wash basins;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sufficient sanitary hand drying facilities to serve the number of employees using the personal service room; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a non-combustible container for the disposal of used towels where towels are provided.

Subsection.Text: A shower room with a door fitted on the inside with a locking device and at least one shower head for every 10 employees or portion of that number shall be provided for employees who regularly perform strenuous physical work in a high temperature or high humidity or whose bodies may be contaminated by a hazardous substance.
Every shower receptor shall be constructed and arranged in such a way that water cannot leak through the walls or floors.
No more than six shower heads shall be served by a single shower drain.
Where two or more shower heads are served by a shower drain, the floor shall be sloped and the drain so located that water from one head cannot flow over the area that serves another head.
Except for column showers, where a battery of shower heads is installed, the horizontal distance between two adjacent shower heads shall be at least 750 mm.

Waterproof finish shall be provided to a height of not less than 1.8 m above the floor in shower rooms and shall consist of ceramic, plastic or metal tile, sheet vinyl, tempered hardboard, laminated thermosetting decorative sheets or linoleum.

Finished flooring in shower rooms shall consist of resilient flooring, felted-synthetic fibre floor coverings, concrete terrazzo, ceramic tile, mastic or other types of flooring providing similar degrees of water resistance.
Where duck boards are used in showers, they shall not be made of wood.
Every shower shall be provided with cold water and hot water that meets the requirements of section 9.18.
Where an employee referred to in subsection (1) takes a shower as a result of his work, a clean towel and soap or other cleaning agent shall be provided to him.

Section.Text: Every employer shall provide potable water for drinking, personal washing and food preparation that meets the standards set out in the Guidelines for Canadian Drinking Water Quality 1978, published by authority of the Minister of National Health and Welfare.
Where it is necessary to transport water for drinking, personal washing or food preparation, only sanitary portable water containers shall be used.
Where a portable storage container for drinking water is used,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the container shall be securely covered and closed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the container shall be used only for the purpose of storing potable water;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the container shall not be stored in a toilet room; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the water shall be drawn from the container by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a tap,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a ladle used only for the purpose of drawing water from the container, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other means that precludes the contamination of the water.

Section.Text: Except where drinking water is supplied by a drinking fountain, sanitary single-use drinking cups shall be provided.
Any ice that is added to drinking water or used for the contact refrigeration of foodstuffs shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be made from potable water; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be so stored and handled as to prevent contamination.

Section.Text: Where drinking water is supplied by a drinking fountain, the fountain shall meet the standards set out in ARI Standard 1010-82, Standard for Drinking-Fountains and Self-Contained, Mechanically-Refrigerated Drinking-Water Coolers, dated 1982.
All field accommodation shall meet the following standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it shall be located on well-drained ground;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it shall be so constructed that it can easily be cleaned and disinfected;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the food preparation area and lunch room shall be separated from the sleeping quarters;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where a water plumbing system is provided, the system shall operate under sanitary conditions;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: garbage disposal facilities shall be provided to prevent the accumulation of garbage;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: toilet rooms shall be maintained in a sanitary condition; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: vermin prevention, heating, ventilation and sanitary sewage systems shall be provided.

Subsection.Text: Living quarters provided

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in any fixed accommodation shall comprise

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for a single occupant, a space of at least 18 m3, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where there is more than one occupant, 18 m3 plus 12 m3 for each additional occupant; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any mobile accommodation shall comprise

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for a single occupant, a space of at least 12 m3, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where there is more than one occupant, 12 m3 plus 8 m3 for each additional occupant.

Subsection.Text: The living quarters referred to in subsection (1) shall have no floor dimension that is less than 1.5 m.
Toilet rooms and locker rooms shall not be counted in the calculation made in accordance with subsection (1).
All mobile accommodation shall meet the standards set out in CSA Standard Z240.2.1-1979, Structural Requirements for Mobile Homes, dated September, 1979, as amended to April, 1984.
For the purposes of clause 4.12.4 of the Standard referred to in subsection (1), there is no other approved method.

Section.Text: In any field accommodation provided as sleeping quarters for employees

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a separate bed or bunk shall be provided for each employee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the beds or bunks shall not be more than double-tiered and shall be so constructed that they can be cleaned and disinfected;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: mattresses, sheets, pillow cases, blankets and bed covers shall be provided for each employee and kept in a clean and sanitary condition;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: clean laundered sheets and pillow cases shall be provided for each employee at least once each week; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: at least one shelf and a locker fitted with a locking device shall be provided for each employee.

Heading.TitleText: Preparation, Handling, Storage and Serving of Food

Subsection.Text: Each food handler shall be instructed and trained in food handling practices that prevent the contamination of food.
No person who is suffering from a communicable disease shall work as a food handler.

Section.Text: Where food is served in a work place, the employer shall adopt and implement Section G of the Sanitation Code for Canada’s Foodservice Industry published by the Canadian Restaurant and Foodservices Association, dated September, 1984, other than items 2 and 11 thereof.

Subsection.Text: Where foods stored by an employer for consumption by employees require refrigeration to prevent them from becoming hazardous to health, the foods shall be maintained at a temperature of 4°C or lower.
Where foods stored by an employer for consumption by employees require freezing to prevent them from becoming hazardous to health, the foods shall be maintained at a temperature of -11°C or lower.

Section.Text: All equipment and utensils that come into contact with food shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designed to be easily cleaned;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: smooth, free from cracks, crevices, pitting or unnecessary indentations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: cleaned to maintain their surfaces in a sanitary condition.

Section.Text: No person shall eat, prepare or store food

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a place where a hazardous substance may contaminate food, dishes or utensils;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a personal service room that contains a toilet, urinal or shower; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in any other place where food is likely to be contaminated.

Subsection.Text: No food waste or garbage shall be stored in a food preparation area.
Food waste and garbage shall be handled and removed from a food preparation area or lunch room in accordance with subsections (3) to (5).
Wet food waste and garbage shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: disposed of by mechanical grinders or choppers connected to sewage disposal lines; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: held in leak-proof, non-absorptive, easily-cleaned containers with tight-fitting covers in a separate enclosed area or container until removal for disposal.

Subsection.Text: Dry food waste and garbage shall be removed or incinerated.
Food waste and garbage containers shall be kept covered and the food waste and garbage removed as frequently as is necessary to prevent unsanitary conditions.
Food waste and garbage containers shall, each time they are emptied, be cleansed and disinfected in an area separate from the food preparation area.

Section.Text: Every lunch room provided by the employer

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be separated from any place where a hazardous substance may contaminate food, dishes or utensils;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall not be used for any purpose that is incompatible with its use as a lunch room;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall not have any dimension of less than 2.3 m;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall have a minimum floor area of 9 m2;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: shall have 1.1 m2 of floor area for each of the employees who normally use the room at any one time;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: shall be furnished with a sufficient number of tables and seats to accommodate adequately the number of employees normally using the lunch room at any one time; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: shall be provided with non-combustible covered receptacles for the disposal of waste food or other waste material.

Subsection.Text: Each personal service room and food preparation area shall be ventilated to provide at least two changes of air per hour

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by mechanical means, where the room is normally used by 10 or more employees at any one time; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by mechanical means or natural ventilation through a window or similar opening, where the room is used by fewer than 10 employees if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the window or similar opening is located on an outside wall of the room, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: not less than 0.2 m2 of unobstructed ventilation is provided for each of the employees who normally use the room at any one time.

Subsection.Text: Where an employer provides ventilation by mechanical means in accordance with paragraph (1)(a), the amount of air provided for a type of room set out in Column I of an item of the schedule to this Part shall be not less than that set out in Column II of that item.

Where an employer provides for the ventilation of a food preparation area or a lunch room by mechanical means in accordance with paragraph (1)(a), the rate of change of air shall be not less than nine litres per second for each employee who is normally employed in the food preparation area at any one time or for each employee who uses the lunch room at any one time.
Subject to subsection (2), any exhaust system from a personal service room containing a toilet or a shower shall not be connected with any other exhaust or air supply system.

The exhaust system for a personal service room containing a toilet or shower may be connected with the exhaust duct of another room at the exhaust fan inlet if the system is connected in such a manner that an exchange of air cannot occur between the rooms.

Section.Text: Clothing storage facilities shall be provided by the employer for the storage of overcoats and outer clothes not worn by employees while they are working.

Subsection.Text: A change room shall be provided by the employer where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the nature of the work engaged in by an employee makes it necessary for that employee to change from street clothes to work clothes for health or safety reasons; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an employee is regularly engaged in work in which his work clothing becomes wet or contaminated by a hazardous substance.

Subsection.Text: Where wet or contaminated work clothing referred to in paragraph (1)(b) is changed, it shall be stored in such a manner that it does not come in contact with clothing that is not wet or contaminated.
No employee shall leave the work place wearing clothing contaminated by a hazardous substance.
Every employer shall supply drying and cleaning facilities for the purpose of drying or cleaning wet or contaminated clothing referred to in paragraph (1)(b).
In each change room,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a floor area of at least 0.4 m2 shall be provided for each of the employees who normally use the room at any one time; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where it is necessary for the employees to change footwear, seats shall be provided in sufficient numbers to accommodate them.

Section.Text: To the extent that is reasonably practicable, the clothing storage facilities referred to in section 9.43 and the change room referred to in section 9.44 shall be located

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: near the work place and connected thereto by a completely covered route;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on a direct route to the entrance to the work place;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: near a shower room provided pursuant to section 9.23; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: near a toilet room.
