Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: airborne asbestos fibres means asbestos fibres that are longer than 5 μm (micrometres) with an aspect ratio equal to or greater than 3:1 and that are carried by the air; (fibres d’amiante aéroportées)
asbestos means actinolite, amosite, anthophyllite, chrysotile, crocidolite and tremolite in their fibrous form; (amiante)
asbestos-containing material means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any article that is manufactured and contains 1% or more asbestos by weight at the time of manufacture or that contains a concentration of 1% or more asbestos as determined in accordance with Method 9002 set out in the document entitled NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, published by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, as amended from time to time, or in accordance with a scientifically proven method used to collect and analyze a representative sample of the material; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any material that contains a concentration of 1% or more asbestos as determined in accordance with Method 9002 set out in the document entitled NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, published by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, as amended from time to time, or in accordance with a scientifically proven method used to collect and analyze a representative sample of the material; (matériau contenant de l’amiante)

Definition.Text: clearance air sampling means the action of taking samples to determine if the concentration of airborne asbestos fibres inside an enclosure is below the limit referred to in section 10.19 to permit the dismantling of a containment system; (échantillonnage de l’air après décontamination)

containment system means an isolation system that is designed to effectively contain asbestos fibre within a designated work area where asbestos-containing material is handled, removed, encapsulated or enclosed; (système de confinement)

encapsulation means the treatment of an asbestos-containing material with a sealant that penetrates the material and binds the asbestos fibres together, and the treatment of the surface of the asbestos-containing material with a sealant that creates a membrane on the surface, to prevent the release of asbestos fibres into the air; (encapsulation)

enclosure means a physical barrier such as drywall, plywood or metal sheeting that, as part of the containment system, isolates asbestos-containing material from adjacent areas in a building to prevent the release of airborne asbestos fibres into those areas; (encloisonnement)
friable means, in respect of asbestos-containing material, that the material, when dry, can be easily crumbled or powdered by hand pressure; (friable)

glove bag means a polyethylene or polyvinyl chloride bag that is affixed around an asbestos-containing source and that permits asbestos-containing material to be removed while minimizing the release of airborne asbestos fibres into the work place; (sac à gants)

hazard information means, in respect of a hazardous substance, information on the proper and safe storage, handling, use and disposal of the hazardous substance, including information relating to the health and physical hazards that it presents; (renseignements sur les risques)

HEPA filter means a high-efficiency particulate air filter that has been tested to ensure efficiency equal to or exceeding 99.97% for removal of airborne particles having a mean aerodynamic diameter of 0.3 µm (micrometres) from the air; (filtre HEPA)

high-risk activity means an activity that involves the handling or disturbance of friable asbestos-containing material or is carried out in proximity to friable asbestos-containing material, that requires a high level of control to prevent exposure to excessive concentrations of airborne asbestos fibres and that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the removal or disturbance of more than 1 m2 of friable asbestos-containing material in a work place, even if the activity is divided into smaller jobs,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the spray application of a sealant to a friable asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the cleaning or removal of air-handling equipment, other than filters, in a building that has sprayed-on fireproofing or sprayed-on thermal insulation that is asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the repair, alteration or demolition of all or part of a kiln, metallurgical furnace or similar structure that contains asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the breaking, cutting, drilling, abrading, grinding, sanding or vibrating of non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the activity is carried out by means of power tools that are not attached to dust-collecting devices equipped with HEPA filters, and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the repair, alteration or demolition of all or part of a building in which asbestos is or was used in the manufacture of products, unless the asbestos was cleaned up and removed; (activité à risque élevé)

Definition.Text: low-risk activity means an activity that involves the handling of asbestos-containing material or is carried out in proximity to non-friable asbestos-containing material and that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the installation or removal of ceiling tiles that are made of non-friable asbestos-containing material and cover an area of less than 7.5 m2,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the installation or removal of other non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the material is not being broken, cut, drilled, abraded, ground, sanded or vibrated and dust is not being generated,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the breaking, cutting, drilling, abrading, grinding, sanding or vibrating of non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the material is wetted to control the spread of dust or fibres and the activity is carried out only by means of non-powered hand-held tools, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of less than 1 m² of drywall in which joint cement containing asbestos has been used; (activité à faible risque)

Definition.Text: moderate-risk activity means an activity that involves the handling of asbestos-containing material or is carried out in proximity to friable asbestos-containing material, that is not otherwise classified as a low-risk activity or high-risk activity and that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of all or part of a false ceiling to gain access to a work area, if asbestos-containing material is likely to be found on the surface of the false ceiling,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the removal or disturbance of 1 m2 or less of friable asbestos-containing material during repair, alteration, maintenance or demolition work in a work place,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the enclosure of friable asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the application of tape, sealant or other covering to pipe or boiler insulation that is asbestos-containing material,

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of ceiling tiles that are asbestos-containing material, if the tiles cover an area of greater than 2 m2 and are removed without being broken, cut, drilled, abraded, ground, sanded or vibrated,

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the breaking, cutting, drilling, abrading, grinding, sanding or vibrating of non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the material is not wetted to control the spread of dust or fibres and the activity is carried out only by means of non-powered hand-held tools,

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of 1 m2 or more of drywall in which joint cement that is asbestos-containing material has been used,

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the breaking, cutting, drilling, abrading, grinding, sanding or vibrating of non-friable asbestos-containing material, if the activity is carried out by means of power tools that are attached to dust-collecting devices equipped with HEPA filters,

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the removal of insulation that is asbestos-containing material from a pipe, duct or similar structure using a glove bag, and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the cleaning or removal of filters used in air-handling equipment in a building that has sprayed-on fireproofing that is asbestos-containing material; (activité à risque modéré)

Definition.Text: product identifier has the same meaning as in subsection 1(1) of the Hazardous Products Regulations; (identificateur de produit)
readily available means, in respect of a document, present and easily accessible at the work place at all times; (facilement accessible)
supplier has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Hazardous Products Act; (fournisseur)

work activity means any low-risk activity, moderate-risk activity or high-risk activity or any activity that is ancillary to that activity, and the supervision of that activity and that ancillary activity. (activité de travail)

Section.Text: This Part does not apply to the handling or transportation of dangerous goods to which the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 and regulations made thereunder apply.

Every employer shall keep and maintain a record of all hazardous substances that, in the work place, are used, produced, handled, or stored for use in the work place, and may either keep and maintain such a record in the work place or keep and maintain a centralized record in respect of several work places, in one work place.

Subsection.Text: If there is a likelihood that the health or safety of an employee in a work place is or may be endangered by exposure to a hazardous substance, the employer shall, without delay,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint a qualified person to carry out an investigation in that regard; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of providing for the participation of the work place committee or the health and safety representative in the investigation, notify either of the proposed investigation and of the name of the qualified person appointed to carry out that investigation.

Subsection.Text: In an investigation referred to in subsection (1), the following criteria shall be taken into consideration:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the chemical, biological and physical properties of the hazardous substance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the routes of exposure to the hazardous substance;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the acute and chronic effects on health of exposure to the hazardous substance;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the quantity of the hazardous substance to be handled;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the manner in which the hazardous substance is stored, used, handled and disposed of;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the control methods used to eliminate or reduce exposure of employees to the hazardous substance;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the concentration or level of the hazardous substance to which an employee is likely to be exposed;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: whether the concentration of an airborne chemical agent or the level of ionizing or non-ionizing radiation is likely to exceed 50 per cent of the values referred to in subsection 10.19(1) or the levels referred to in subsections 10.26(3) and (4); and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: whether the level referred to in paragraph (g) is likely to exceed or be less than that prescribed in Part VI.

Section.Text: On completion of an investigation referred to in subsection 10.4(1) and after consultation with the work place committee or the health and safety representative,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the qualified person shall set out in a written report signed by the qualified person

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the qualified person’s observations respecting the criteria considered in accordance with subsection 10.4(2), and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the qualified person’s recommendations respecting the manner of compliance with sections 10.7 to 10.26, including recommendations respecting sampling and testing methods; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employer shall develop and maintain a written procedure for the control of the concentration or level of the hazardous substance in the work place and make it readily available for examination by employees in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Section.Text: A report referred to in section 10.5 shall be kept by the employer for a period of thirty years after the date on which the qualified person signed the report.

Subsection.Text: Where a report referred to in section 10.5 recommends a medical examination for the employees likely to be exposed to a hazardous substance, the employer shall consult a physician to ascertain the necessity for that medical examination.

The employer, having consulted a physician pursuant to subsection (1) who has confirmed the necessity for a medical examination, shall not permit an employee to handle the hazardous substance in the work place unless a physician acceptable to the employee has examined the employee and declared the employee fit, or fit with specified restrictions, to handle the hazardous substance.

Where the physician examining an employee pursuant to subsection (2) declares the employee fit with specified restrictions to handle the hazardous substance, the employer shall not permit the employee to handle the hazardous substance in the work place except in accordance with the specified restrictions.
Where an employer consults a physician pursuant to subsection (1), the employer shall keep a copy of the physician’s decision with the report referred to in section 10.5.
The cost of a medical examination referred to in subsection (2) shall be borne by the employer.

Section.Text: Every hazardous substance stored, handled or used in a work place shall be stored, handled or used in a manner whereby the hazard related to that substance is reduced to a minimum.
Where a hazardous substance is stored, handled or used in a work place, any hazard resulting from that storage, handling or use shall be confined to as small an area as is practicable.

Every container for a hazardous substance that is used in a work place shall be so designed and constructed that it protects the employees from any health or safety hazard that is caused by the hazardous substance.
The quantity of a hazardous substance for use or processing in a work place shall, to the extent that is practicable, be limited to the quantity required for one work day.

Subsection.Text: Where, in a work place, a hazardous substance is capable of combining with another substance to form an ignitable combination and there exists a hazard of ignition of the combination by static electricity, the employer shall implement the standards set out in the United States National Fire Protection Association, Inc. publication NFPA 77, Recommended Practice on Static Electricity, dated 1988, as amended from time to time.
For the purpose of interpreting the standards referred to in subsection (1), acceptable means appropriate.

Section.Text: Where a hazardous substance is stored, handled or used in a work place, warnings shall be given in appropriate places at access points warning every person granted access to the work place of the presence of the hazardous substance and of any precautions to be taken to prevent or reduce any hazard of injury to health.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall, in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, develop and implement an employee education and training program with respect to hazard prevention and control at the work place.
The employee education and training program shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the education and training of each employee who is likely to handle or be exposed to a hazardous substance, with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the product identifier of the hazardous substance,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: all hazard information disclosed by the supplier or by the employer on a safety data sheet or label,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: all hazard information of which the employer is aware or ought to be aware,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the observations referred to in subparagraph 10.5(a)(i),

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the information disclosed on a safety data sheet referred to in section 10.28 and the purpose and significance of that information, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: in respect of hazardous products in the work place, the information required to be disclosed on a safety data sheet and on a label under Division III and the purpose and significance of that information;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the education and training of each employee who installs, operates, maintains or repairs an assembly of pipes or any other equipment referred to in section 10.24, with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: every valve and other control and safety device connected to the assembly of pipes,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to follow for the proper and safe use of the assembly of pipes, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the significance of the labelling, colour-coding, placarding or other modes of identification that are used;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the education and training of each employee who is referred to in paragraph (a) or (b), with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to follow to implement sections 10.8, 10.9 and 10.12,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to follow for the safe storage, handling, use and disposal of hazardous substances, including procedures to be followed in an emergency involving a hazardous substance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the procedures to follow if an employee is exposed to fugitive emissions as defined in section 10.29; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the education and training of each employee on the procedures to follow to access electronic or paper versions of reports, records of education and training given and safety data sheets.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall, in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, review and, if necessary, revise the employee education and training program

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least once a year;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whenever there is a change in conditions in respect of the presence of hazardous substances in the work place; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whenever new hazard information in respect of a hazardous substance in the work place becomes available to the employer.

Section.Text: The employer shall keep a paper or electronic record of the education and training given to every employee and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make it readily available for examination by the employee in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep it for a period of two years after the employee ceases

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to handle or be exposed to the hazardous substance, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to install, operate, maintain or repair the assembly of pipes.

Subsection.Text: No person shall use a hazardous substance in a work place where it is reasonably practicable to substitute a substance for it that is not a hazardous substance.

Where a hazardous substance is to be used for any purpose in a work place and an equivalent substance that is less hazardous is available to be used for that purpose, the equivalent substance shall be substituted for the hazardous substance where reasonably practicable.

Every ventilation system installed on or after January 1, 1997 to control the concentration of an airborne hazardous substance shall be so designed, constructed, installed, operated and maintained that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the concentration of the airborne hazardous substance does not exceed the values and levels prescribed in subsections 10.19(1) and 10.20(1) and (2); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it meets the standards set out in

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Part 6 of the National Building Code,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the publication of the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists entitled Industrial Ventilation, 20th edition, dated 1988, as amended from time to time, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: ANSI Standard ANSI Z9.2-1979 entitled Fundamentals Governing the Design and Operation of Local Exhaust Systems, dated 1979, as amended from time to time.

Subsection.Text: To the extent that is reasonably practicable, every ventilation system installed before January 1, 1997 to control the concentration of an airborne hazardous substance shall be maintained so as to meet the requirements set out in subsection (1).

Before a ventilation system referred to in subsection 10.17(1) is operated for the first time in a work place, the employer shall set out in writing instructions pertaining to the inspection, testing and maintenance of that ventilation system.
The instructions referred to in subsection (1) shall specify the nature and frequency of inspections, tests and maintenance to be performed on the ventilation system.
The employer shall ensure that a qualified person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: carries out each inspection, testing and maintenance of the ventilation system in accordance with the instructions referred to in subsection (1); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: makes and signs a report with respect to each inspection, test or maintenance work.

Subsection.Text: A report referred to in paragraph (3)(b) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: include the date of the inspection, test or maintenance work performed by the qualified person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify the ventilation system that was inspected, tested or maintained; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set out the safety observations of the qualified person in respect of the ventilation system.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall keep at the work place at which the ventilation system is located a copy of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the instructions referred to in subsection (1), and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the most recent report referred to in paragraph (3)(b).

Subsection.Text: The employer shall give to every employee who operates a ventilation system the necessary education and training for the safe and proper use of the system.

The employer shall keep a paper or electronic record of the education and training given to every employee who operates a ventilation system for as long as the employee remains in the employer’s employ.
An employee shall be kept free from exposure to a concentration of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an airborne chemical agent, other than grain dust or airborne asbestos fibres, in excess of the value for that chemical agent adopted by the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists in its publication entitled Threshold Limit Values (TLVs) and Biological Exposure Indices (BEIs), as amended from time to time; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: airborne grain dust in excess of 10 mg/m3.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall ensure that an employee’s exposure to a concentration of airborne asbestos fibres is as close to zero as is reasonably practicable, but in any event the employer shall ensure that the concentration is not in excess of the value for airborne asbestos fibres adopted by the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists in its publication entitled Threshold Limit Values (TLVs) and Biological Exposure Indices (BEIs), as amended from time to time.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of concentrations of carbon dioxide or respirable dust in the underground portion of a coal mine.

If there is a likelihood that the concentration of an airborne chemical agent may exceed any value referred to in subsection (1) or that the concentration of airborne asbestos fibres may exceed zero, air samples shall be taken by a qualified person and the concentration of the chemical agent or the airborne asbestos fibres shall be determined

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the standards set out by the American Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists in its publication entitled Manual of Analytical Methods Recommended for Sampling and Analysis of Atmospheric Contaminants, dated 1958, as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with the standards set out by the United States National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health in the NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, third edition, volumes 1 and 2, dated February, 1984, as amended from time to time;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in accordance with a method that collects and analyses a representative sample of the chemical agent with accuracy and with detection levels at least equal to those which would be obtained if the standards referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) were used; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: where no specific standards for the chemical agent are set out in the publications referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) and no method is available under paragraph (c), in accordance with a scientifically proven method used to collect and analyse a representative sample of the chemical agent.

Subsection.Text: A paper or electronic record of each test made under subsection (3) shall be kept by the employer at the employer’s place of business that is nearest to the work place where the air sample was taken, for a period of three years after the date of the test.
A record referred to in subsection (4) shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and location of the test;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazardous substance in respect of which the test was made;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the sampling and testing method used;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the result obtained; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name and occupation of the person who made the test.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), the concentration of an airborne chemical agent or combination of airborne chemical agents in the work place shall be less than 50 per cent of the lower explosive limit of the chemical agent or combination of chemical agents.

Where a source of ignition may ignite an airborne chemical agent or combination of airborne chemical agents in the work place, the maximum concentration of the chemical agent or of the combination of chemical agents shall be 10 per cent of the lower explosive limit of the chemical agent or combination of chemical agents.
Subsection (2) does not apply in respect of concentrations of methane gas in the underground portion of a coal mine.
Compressed air, gas or steam shall not be used for blowing dust or other substances from structures, machinery or materials where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: there is a risk of any person being directly exposed to the jet or where a fire, explosion, injury or health hazard is likely to result from such use; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: such use would result in a concentration of an airborne hazardous substance that is in excess of the value referred to in paragraph 10.19(1)(a) or subsection 10.19(1.1) or the limit referred to in subsection 10.20(1) or (2).

Subsection.Text: Compressed air shall not be used for cleaning clothing contaminated with:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: asbestos; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a hazardous substance having an exposure limit referred to in paragraph 10.19(1)(a) or (b) lower than 1 mg/m3.

Subsection.Text: Where compressed air is used to clean clothing,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appropriate eye protection shall be worn; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum compressed air pressure in the pipeline shall be 69 kPa (10 psi) or a safety nozzle limiting the air pressure to no more than 69kPa (10 psi) shall be used.

Section.Text: Where reasonably practicable, the employer shall provide automated warning and detection systems where the seriousness of any exposure to a hazardous substance so requires.
Every assembly of pipes, pipe fittings, valves, safety devices, pumps, compressors and other fixed equipment that is used for transferring a hazardous substance from one location to another shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: marked, by labelling, colour-coding, placarding or any other mode, to identify the hazardous substance being transferred and, if appropriate, the direction of the flow; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fitted with valves and other control and safety devices to ensure its safe operation, maintenance and repair.

Section.Text: All blasting using dynamite or other explosives shall be done by a qualified person who, where required under the laws of the province in which the blasting is carried out, holds a blasting certificate or such other authorization as may be required under those laws.

Subsection.Text: Where a device that is capable of producing and emitting energy in the form of ionizing or non-ionizing radiation is used in the work place, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the device is listed in the schedule to this Division, make a report in writing to the Consumer and Clinical Radiation Protection Bureau of the Department of Health, setting out a description of the device and the location of the work place; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the device is referred to in subsection (2), implement the applicable document, as amended from time to time, published by the Department of National Health and Welfare, as specified in one of paragraphs (2)(a) to (k) or published by ANSI, as specified in paragraph (2)(l).

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph (1)(b), the applicable document is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of radio frequency and microwave devices in the frequency range from 10 kHz to 300 GHz, Safety Code - 6, dated 1990;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of X-ray equipment in medical diagnosis, Safety Code - 20A, dated 1980;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of baggage inspection X-ray equipment, Safety Code - 21, dated 1978;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of dental X-ray equipment, Safety Code - 22, dated 1980;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of ultrasound equipment, Safety Code - 23, dated 1989, and Safety Code - 24, dated 1990;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of short-wave diathermy equipment, Safety Code - 25, dated 1983;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of magnetic resonance imaging and magnetic resonance spectroscopy equipment, Safety Code - 26, dated 1987;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of industrial X-ray equipment, Safety Code - 27, dated 1987;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of veterinary X-ray equipment, Safety Code - 28, dated 1991;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of demonstration-type discharge devices, Recommended Safety Procedures for the Selection and Use of Demonstration-Type Discharge Devices in Schools, dated 1979;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of dielectric (RF) heaters, Dielectric (RF) Heaters Guidelines for Limiting Radio-Frequency Exposure, dated 1980; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of lasers, ANSI Standard ANSI Z136.1-1986, American National Standard for the Safe Use of Lasers, dated 1986, including its appendices with the exception of Appendix D.

Subsection.Text: If an employee works on or near a device that may emit nuclear energy, the employer shall ensure that the exposure of the employee to nuclear energy does not exceed the radiation dose limits set out in the Radiation Protection Regulations.

No employee, other than a nuclear energy worker as defined in section 2 of the Nuclear Safety and Control Act, shall be exposed in the course of any year to a concentration of radon that on average, over the year, is higher than 800 Bq/m3.

Heading.Label: DIVISION II
Heading.TitleText: Hazardous Substances Other than Hazardous Products

Subsection.Text: If asbestos-containing material is present in a work place and there is the potential for a release of asbestos fibres or employee exposure to asbestos fibres, an employer shall ensure that the qualified person who is carrying out a hazard investigation under section 10.4 takes into consideration the type of asbestos, the condition of the asbestos-containing material, the friability of the asbestos-containing material, the accessibility to and likelihood of damage to the asbestos-containing material and the potential for the release of asbestos fibres and employee exposure to asbestos fibres.

At the completion of an investigation carried out under section 10.4, the employer shall ensure that a readily available record of the location, friability and condition of the asbestos-containing material and the type of asbestos contained in the asbestos-containing material is kept and maintained for examination by employees and is in any form as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Section.Text: Before undertaking any work activity that involves asbestos-containing material, an employer shall, in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative, develop, implement and administer an asbestos exposure control plan that requires the employer to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that a hazard investigation under section 10.4 has been carried out by a qualified person and, in the event that there is a change in the work activity, review any report that was prepared as a result of the investigation and, if necessary, have a qualified person carry out another investigation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that a qualified person classifies the work activity as a low-risk activity, moderate-risk activity or high-risk activity;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that all asbestos-containing material present in the work place that is exposed or that will be disturbed is identified by signs and labels or by any other effective manner;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that all friable asbestos-containing material present in the work place is controlled by removal, enclosure or encapsulation or by any other effective manner to prevent employee exposure to asbestos;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that procedures and control measures for moderate-risk activities and high-risk activities are developed and implemented; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: develop and implement an employee education and training program that is specific to asbestos-containing material.

Section.Text: If an employee who is undertaking automotive service procedures may be exposed to asbestos from friction material or dust arising from that material, an employer shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the use of compressed air, brushes or similar means to dry-remove friction material dust from automotive assemblies is prohibited; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: signs to advise employees of the hazards and required precautions are posted in service work areas where friction material is handled or dust arising from that material is generated.

Heading.TitleText: Asbestos Dust, Waste and Debris Removal

Subsection.Text: During any work activities that involve friable asbestos-containing materials, an employer shall ensure that the following activities are carried out frequently and at regular intervals as determined by a qualified person, at the end of each work shift and immediately after the work activity is completed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all asbestos dust, waste and debris are removed by vacuuming with a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter, damp-mopping or wet-sweeping the area that is contaminated with the asbestos dust, waste or debris; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any drop sheets that are contaminated with asbestos dust, waste or debris are wetted.

Subsection.Text: All asbestos dust, waste or debris and any drop sheets that are contaminated with asbestos dust, waste or debris shall be placed in a container referred to in section 10.26.11.

Section.Text: If a glove bag is used for the removal of asbestos insulation from pipes, ducts and similar structures, an employer shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the glove bag is sealed to prevent the release of asbestos fibres into the work area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the glove bag is inspected for damage or defects immediately before it is attached to the pipe, duct or similar structure and at regular intervals during its use;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all waste from asbestos-containing material that is on surfaces is washed to the bottom of the glove bag and all exposed asbestos-containing material is encapsulated when it is inside the glove bag;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the glove bag is evacuated using a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter to remove the air inside the bag prior to the removal of the glove bag; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: after the glove bag is removed, all exposed surfaces are cleaned with a damp cloth and a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter.

Subsection.Text: Before leaving a work area that is contaminated with asbestos-containing material, an employee shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if their protective clothing is to be reused, decontaminate the clothing with a damp cloth or a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter before taking the clothing off; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if their protective clothing is not to be reused, place the clothing in a container referred to in section 10.26.11.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall provide employees with a facility reserved for washing their hands and face, and employees shall wash their hands and face using that facility before leaving a work area that is contaminated with asbestos-containing material.

Section.Text: As soon as practicable after any work activity that involves asbestos-containing material is completed, an employee shall clean reusable tools, equipment, rigid barriers and portable enclosures that are contaminated with asbestos with a damp cloth or a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall ensure that a qualified person takes air samples to test for airborne asbestos fibres

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the vicinity of the containment system during any work activity that involves asbestos-containing material and, in the case of a work activity that lasts longer than 24 hours, at least daily;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the clean room during removal and clean-up operations and, in the case of removal and clean-up operations that last longer than 24 hours, at least daily; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in contaminated areas that are inside the containment system as necessary during removal and clean-up operations.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall ensure that the following air samples are taken:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two samples for every area in an enclosure that is 10 m2 or less;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: three samples for every area in an enclosure that is more than 10 m2 and not more than 500 m2; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: five samples for every area in an enclosure that is more than 500 m2.

Subsection.Text: Within 24 hours after obtaining the air sampling test results, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post a copy of the results in a conspicuous place in the work place; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make the results available to the policy committee, if any, the work place committee and the health and safety representative.

Subsection.Text: Before dismantling a containment system and after all asbestos dust, waste and debris have been cleaned up, removed or encapsulated, an employer shall ensure that clearance air samples are taken inside the enclosure and that the concentration of airborne asbestos fibres is determined in accordance with Method 7400 set out in the document entitled NIOSH Manual of Analytical Methods, published by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, as amended from time to time, or in accordance with a scientifically proven method used to collect and analyze a representative sample of airborne asbestos fibres.
When conducting clearance air sampling, the employer shall ensure that forced air is used inside the enclosure to dislodge any asbestos fibres from all surfaces and keep them airborne.
Clearance air sampling shall be taken until the concentrations of airborne asbestos fibres do not exceed the values referred to in subsection 10.19(1.1).

Section.Text: Within 24 hours after obtaining the clearance air sampling test results, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: post a copy of the results in a conspicuous place in the work place; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make the results available to the policy committee, if any, the work place committee and the health and safety representative, and provide a copy of the results to the Minister.

Heading.TitleText: Containers for Asbestos Dust, Waste and Debris

Section.Text: Containers for the containment of asbestos dust, waste and debris and asbestos-containing material shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: dust-tight;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: suitable to contain asbestos dust, waste or debris;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: impervious to asbestos;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: identified as containing asbestos dust, waste or debris;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: cleaned with a damp cloth or a vacuum cleaner that is equipped with a HEPA filter immediately before being removed from the work area; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: removed from the work place frequently and at regular intervals as determined by a qualified person.

Section.Text: Every container of a hazardous substance, other than a hazardous product, that is stored, handled, used or disposed of in the work place shall be labelled in a manner that discloses clearly

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the generic name of the substance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazard information in respect of the substance.

Section.Text: If a safety data sheet in respect of a hazardous substance, other than a hazardous product, that is stored, handled or used in the work place may be obtained from the supplier of the hazardous substance, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: obtain a copy of the safety data sheet; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep the copy of the safety data sheet readily available for examination by employees in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Section.Text: In this Division,

Definition.Text: bulk shipment has the same meaning as in subsection 5.5(1) of the Hazardous Products Regulations; (expédition en vrac)
container means any package or receptacle, including a bag, barrel, bottle, box, can, cylinder, drum and storage tank; (contenant)

fugitive emission means a hazardous product in gas, liquid, solid, vapour, fume, mist, fog or dust form that escapes from processing equipment, from control emission equipment or from a product into the work place; (émission fugitive)
hazardous waste means a hazardous product that is acquired or generated for recycling or recovery or is intended for disposal; (résidu dangereux)
laboratory sample has the same meaning as in subsection 5(1) of the Hazardous Products Regulations; (échantillon pour laboratoire)

research and development, in respect of a hazardous product, means systematic investigation or search carried out in a field of science or technology by means of experiment or analysis, other than investigation or search in respect of market research, sales promotion, quality control or routine testing of hazardous products, and includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: applied research, namely, work undertaken for the advancement of scientific knowledge with a specific practical application in view, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: development, namely, use of the results of applied research for the purpose of creating new, or improving existing, processes or hazardous products; (recherche et développement)

Definition.Text: risk phrase, in respect of a hazardous product, means a statement identifying a hazard that may arise from the exposure to the hazardous product; (mention de risque)
sale includes offer for sale, expose for sale and distribute; (vente)
significant new data has the same meaning as in subsection 5.12(1) of the Hazardous Products Regulations; (nouvelles données importantes)
supplier label means a label prepared by a supplier that discloses any information elements required by the Hazardous Products Act; (étiquette du fournisseur)

supplier safety data sheet means a safety data sheet prepared by a supplier that discloses any information elements required by the Hazardous Products Act; (fiche de données de sécurité du fournisseur)
work place label means a label prepared by an employer in accordance with this Division; (étiquette du lieu de travail)

Text.DefinedTermEn: work place material safety data sheet

Definition.Text: work place safety data sheet means a safety data sheet prepared by an employer in accordance with subsection 10.33(1) or (2). (fiche de données de sécurité du lieu de travail)

Subsection.Text: This Division does not apply in respect of any

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: tobacco or a tobacco product as defined in section 2 of the Tobacco and Vaping Products Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: manufactured article as defined in section 2 of the Hazardous Products Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: wood or a product made of wood.

Subsection.Text: This Division, other than section 10.43, does not apply in respect of hazardous waste.

Heading.TitleText: Safety Data Sheets and Labels in Respect of Certain Hazardous Products

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2) and section 10.42, every employer shall implement the provisions of sections 10.27 and 10.28 in respect of a hazardous product and may, in so doing, replace the generic name of the product with the brand name, chemical name, common name or trade name, if the hazardous product

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is present in the work place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: was received from a supplier; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is one of the following:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a hazardous product, other than wood or a product made of wood, that is listed in Schedule 1 to the Hazardous Products Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a nuclear substance, as defined in section 2 of the Nuclear Safety and Control Act, that is radioactive.

Subsection.Text: An employer may store a hazardous product received from a supplier without having a supplier label on it, without having obtained a safety data sheet for it and without having conducted an employee education and training program with respect to the matters referred to in subparagraphs 10.14(2)(a)(ii) and (c)(ii)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: while the employer is actively seeking a supplier label and a supplier safety data sheet for the hazardous product; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if labelling affixed to the container of the hazardous product containing information on the hazardous product is not removed, defaced, modified or altered.

Subsection.Text: If a hazardous product, other than a hazardous product referred to in paragraph 10.31(1)(c), is received in the work place by an employer, the employer shall, without delay, obtain a supplier safety data sheet in respect of the hazardous product from the supplier, unless the employer is already in possession of a supplier safety data sheet that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is for a hazardous product that both has the same product identifier and is from the same supplier;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: discloses information that is current at the time that the hazardous product is received; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: was prepared and dated less than three years before the day on which the hazardous product is received.

Subsection.Text: If the supplier safety data sheet in respect of a hazardous product in a work place is three years old or more, the employer shall, if possible, obtain from the supplier a current supplier safety data sheet.

If it is not practicable for an employer to obtain a current supplier safety data sheet, the employer shall update the hazard information on the most recent supplier safety data sheet that the employer has received, on the basis of the ingredients disclosed on that supplier safety data sheet and on the basis of any significant new data of which the employer is aware.

The employer is exempt from the requirements of subsection (1) if a laboratory sample of a hazardous product is received in the work place from a supplier who is exempted by the Hazardous Products Regulations from the requirement to provide a safety data sheet for that product.

Subject to section 10.42, if an employer produces in the work place a hazardous product, other than a fugitive emission or an intermediate product undergoing reaction within a reaction or process vessel, or imports into Canada a hazardous product and brings it into the work place, the employer shall prepare a work place safety data sheet in respect of that hazardous product.

Subject to section 10.42, if an employer receives a supplier safety data sheet, the employer may prepare a work place safety data sheet to be used in the work place in place of the supplier safety data sheet if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the work place safety data sheet discloses at least the information disclosed on the supplier safety data sheet;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the information disclosed on the work place safety data sheet does not disclaim or contradict the information disclosed on the supplier safety data sheet;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the supplier safety data sheet is readily available for examination by employees in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the work place safety data sheet discloses that the supplier safety data sheet is available in the work place.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall review the accuracy of the information disclosed on a work place safety data sheet referred to in subsection (1) or (2) and update it as soon as practicable after new hazard information or significant new data becomes available to the employer.

If the information required to be disclosed on the work place safety data sheet is not available or not applicable to the hazardous product, the employer shall, in place of the information, insert the words “not available” or “not applicable”, as the case may be, in the English version and the words “non disponible” or “sans objet”, as the case may be, in the French version, of the work place safety data sheet.

Every employer shall keep readily available for examination by employees and by any policy committee, work place committee or health and safety representative in any work place in which an employee is likely to handle or be exposed to a hazardous product a copy, in English and in French, of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an employer referred to in subsection 10.33(1) or (2), the work place safety data sheet; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, the supplier safety data sheet.

Subsection.Text: The work place safety data sheet and supplier safety data sheet shall be made available in any form, as determined in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Subject to sections 10.37 to 10.39, each hazardous product, other than a hazardous product referred to in paragraph 10.31(1)(c), in a work place and each container in which the hazardous product is contained in a work place shall, if the hazardous product or the container is received from a supplier,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case where the hazardous product is in a bulk shipment, be accompanied by a supplier label;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case where the employer has undertaken in writing to apply a label to the inner container of the hazardous product, have applied to it a supplier label as soon as possible after the hazardous product is received from the supplier; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, have applied to it a supplier label.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 10.37 to 10.39 and 10.42, if a hazardous product, other than a hazardous product referred to in paragraph 10.31(1)(c), is received from a supplier and an employer places the hazardous product in the work place in a container other than the container in which it was received from the supplier, the employer shall apply to the container a supplier label or work place label that discloses the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the product identifier;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazard information in respect of the hazardous product; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement indicating that a safety data sheet for the hazardous product is available in the work place.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 10.41 and 10.42, no person shall remove, deface, modify or alter the supplier label applied to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a hazardous product that is in the work place; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the container of a hazardous product that is in the work place.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 10.37 to 10.39, if an employer produces in the work place a hazardous product, other than a fugitive emission, or imports into Canada a hazardous product and brings it into the work place, and the hazardous product is not in a container, the employer shall disclose the following information on a work place label applied to the hazardous product or on a sign posted in a conspicuous place in the work place:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the product identifier;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazard information in respect of the hazardous product; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement indicating that a work place safety data sheet for the hazardous product is available in the work place.

Subsection.Text: Subject to sections 10.37 and 10.39, where an employer produces a hazardous product in the work place, other than a fugitive emission, or imports into Canada and brings into the work place a hazardous product, and places the hazardous product in a container, the employer shall apply to the container a work place label that discloses the information referred to in paragraphs (1)(a) to (c).
Subsection (2) does not apply in respect of a hazardous product that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: intended for export, if the information referred to in paragraphs (1)(a) to (c) is disclosed on a sign posted in a conspicuous place in the work place; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: packaged in a container and offered for sale in Canada, if the container is or is in the process of being appropriately labelled for that purpose.

Section.Text: If an employer stores a hazardous product in the work place in a container that has applied to it a supplier label or a work place label, a portable container filled from that container is exempted from the labelling requirements under section 10.35 or 10.36 if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the hazardous product is required for immediate use; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the following conditions apply in respect of the hazardous product:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: it is under the control of and used exclusively by the employee who filled the portable container,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: it is used only during the work shift in which the portable container was filled, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: it is clearly identified by a work place label applied to the portable container that discloses the product identifier.

Section.Text: An employer shall, in a conspicuous place near a hazardous product, post a sign in respect of the hazardous product that discloses the product identifier if the hazardous product is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a process, reaction or storage vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a continuous-run container;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in a bulk shipment that is not placed in a container at the work place; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: not in a container and stored in bulk.

Subsection.Text: If a laboratory sample of a hazardous product is the subject of a labelling exemption under subsection 5(5) of the Hazardous Products Regulations, a label that is provided by the supplier and is affixed to, printed on or attached to the container of the sample received at the work place and that discloses the following information in place of the information required under paragraph 3(1)(d) of those Regulations is considered to comply with the requirements set out in section 10.35 with respect to a supplier label:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if known by the supplier, the chemical name or generic chemical name of any material that is in the hazardous product and that is classified under the Hazardous Products Act and the Hazardous Products Regulations as a biohazardous infectious material; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the statement “Hazardous Laboratory Sample. For hazard information or in an emergency, call/Échantillon pour laboratoire de produit dangereux. Pour obtenir des renseignements sur les dangers ou en cas d’urgence, composez”, followed by an emergency telephone number for the purpose of obtaining the information that must be provided on the safety data sheet of a hazardous product.

Subsection.Text: If a laboratory sample of a hazardous product is the subject of a labelling exemption under subsection 5(6) of the Hazardous Products Regulations, a label that is provided by the supplier and is affixed to, printed on or attached to the container of the sample received at the work place and that discloses the following information in place of the information required under paragraph 3(1)(c) or (d) of those Regulations is considered to comply with the requirements set out in section 10.35 with respect to a supplier label:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if known by the supplier, the chemical name or generic chemical name of any material or substance that is in the hazardous product and that is referred to in subsection 3(2) of Schedule 1 to the Hazardous Products Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the statement “Hazardous Laboratory Sample. For hazard information or in an emergency, call/Échantillon pour laboratoire de produit dangereux. Pour obtenir des renseignements sur les dangers ou en cas d’urgence, composez”, followed by an emergency telephone number for the purpose of obtaining the information that must be provided on the safety data sheet of a hazardous product.

Subsection.Text: If a hazardous product is in a container other than the container in which it was received from a supplier or is produced in the work place, the employer is exempt from the requirements set out in section 10.36 and subparagraph 10.37(b)(iii) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the employer has complied with subsection (4);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: employee education and training is provided as required by these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the hazardous product

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a laboratory sample,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is intended by the employer to be used solely for analysis, testing or evaluation in a laboratory, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: is clearly identified through any mode of identification visible to employees at the work place.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of paragraph (3)(a), the employer shall ensure that the mode of identification used and the employee education and training provided enable the employees to readily identify and obtain either the information required on a safety data sheet or the information set out in subsections (1) and (2) with respect to the hazardous product or laboratory sample.

The employer is exempt from the requirements of section 10.35 if a laboratory sample of a hazardous product is received in a work place from a supplier who is exempted by the Hazardous Products Regulations from the requirement to provide a label for that product.

Section.Text: The information disclosed on a sign referred to in subsection 10.36(1), paragraph 10.36(3)(a), section 10.38 or paragraph 10.43(b) shall be of such a size that it is clearly legible to employees.

Subsection.Text: If, in a work place, a label applied to a hazardous product or the container of a hazardous product becomes illegible or is removed from the hazardous product or the container, the employer shall replace the label with a work place label that discloses the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the product identifier;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the hazard information in respect of the hazardous product; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement indicating that a safety data sheet for the hazardous product is available in the work place.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall review the accuracy of the information on a work place label and update it as soon as practicable after new hazard information or significant new data becomes available to the employer.

Subject to subsection (2), if an employer has filed a claim for exemption from the requirement to disclose information on a safety data sheet or on a label under subsection 11(2) of the Hazardous Materials Information Review Act, the employer shall disclose, in place of the information that the employer is exempt from disclosing,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if there is no final disposition of the proceedings in relation to the claim, the date on which the claim for exemption was filed and the registry number assigned to the claim under section 10 of the Hazardous Materials Information Review Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the final disposition of the proceedings in relation to the claim is that the claim is valid, a statement that an exemption has been granted and the date on which the exemption was granted.

Subsection.Text: If a claim for exemption is in respect of a product identifier, the employer shall, on the safety data sheet or label of the hazardous product, disclose, in place of that product identifier, a code name or code number specified by the employer as the product identifier for that hazardous product.
If a hazardous product in the work place is hazardous waste, the employer shall disclose the generic name and hazard information in respect of the hazardous product by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: applying a label to the hazardous waste or its container; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: posting a sign in a conspicuous place near the hazardous waste or its container.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall provide education and training to employees regarding the safe storage and handling of hazardous waste that is found in the work place.

Heading.TitleText: Information Required in a Medical Emergency

Section.Text: For the purposes of subsection 125.2(1) of the Act, a medical professional is a registered nurse registered or licensed under the laws of a province.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of interpreting the standards referred to in sections 10.46 to 10.49,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: dangerous goods means hazardous products used in these Regulations; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of a hazardous product classified under the Hazardous Products Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: flammable liquids means flammable liquids used in these Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: combustible liquids means combustible liquids used in these Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: compressed gases means compressed gases used in these Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: reactive substances means reactive flammable materials used in these Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: aerosol products means flammable aerosols used in these Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: poisonous and infectious substances means poisonous and infectious materials used in these Regulations,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: corrosive substances" means corrosive materials used in these Regulations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: oxidizing substances means oxidizing materials used in these Regulations.

Section.Text: Hazardous products shall be stored in accordance with subsections 3.2.7, 3.2.8, 3.2.9 and 3.3.4 of the National Fire Code.
Flammable aerosols shall be stored in accordance with subsection 3.2.5 of the National Fire Code.
The provisions of Part 3 of the National Fire Code apply as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: compressed gases shall be stored and handled in accordance with subsections 3.2.8 and 3.3.5;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: reactive flammable materials shall be stored and handled in accordance with subsections 3.2.7 and 3.3.4;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: poisonous and infectious materials shall be stored and handled in accordance with subsections 3.2.7, 3.2.8 and 3.3.4;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: corrosive materials shall be stored and handled in accordance with subsections 3.2.7, 3.2.8 and 3.3.4; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: oxidizing materials shall be stored and handled in accordance with subsections 3.2.7, 3.2.8 and 3.3.4.

Section.Text: The provisions of Part 4 of the National Fire Code apply as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: areas used for the storage, handling and use of flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall meet the standards set out in subsection 4.1.5, with the exception of article 4.1.5.6;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the drainage and disposal of flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall be in accordance with subsection 4.1.6;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall be stored in storage tanks meeting the standards set out in subsection 4.1.8;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: maintenance and operating procedures shall be established to prevent the escape of flammable liquids and combustible liquids, as required by subsection 4.1.6;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: general container storage and handling of flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall be in accordance with subsections 4.2.1 to 4.2.8, with the exception of paragraph 4.2.8.4(d);

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: rooms used for container storage of flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall conform with subsection 4.2.9, with the exception of article 4.2.9.3;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: cabinets used for container storage of flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall conform with subsection 4.2.10;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: outdoor container storage of flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall be in accordance with subsection 4.2.11;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: storage tanks for flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall conform with section 4.3, with the exception of paragraph 4.3.13.1(1)(d), articles 4.3.13.5 and 4.3.15.2 and sentences 4.3.16.1(3) and (4);

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: piping and transfer systems for flammable liquids and combustible liquids shall conform with section 4.4, with the exception of articles 4.4.6.2, 4.4.11.1 and 4.4.11.2; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: flammable liquid and combustible liquid installations on piers and wharves shall conform with section 4.7, with the exception of article 4.7.10.2.

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: class of confined spaces means a group of at least two confined spaces that are likely, by reason of their similarity, to present the same hazards to persons entering, exiting or occupying them; (catégorie d’espaces clos)
confined space means an enclosed or partially enclosed space that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is not designed or intended for human occupancy except for the purpose of performing work,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has restricted means of access and egress, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: may become hazardous to any person entering it owing to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: its design, construction, location or atmosphere,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the materials or substances in it, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: any other conditions relating to it; (espace clos)

Definition.Text: hot work means any work where flame is used or a source of ignition may be produced. (travail à chaud)

Subsection.Text: Where it is likely that a person will, in order to perform work for an employer, enter a confined space and an assessment pursuant to this subsection has not been carried out in respect of the confined space, or in respect of the class of confined spaces to which it belongs, the employer shall appoint a qualified person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to carry out an assessment of the physical and chemical hazards to which the person is likely to be exposed in the confined space or the class of confined spaces; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to specify the tests that are necessary to determine whether the person would be likely to be exposed to any of the hazards identified pursuant to paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: The qualified person referred to in subsection (1) shall, in a signed and dated report to the employer, record the findings of the assessment carried out pursuant to paragraph (1)(a).
The employer shall make a copy of any report made pursuant to subsection (2) available to the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Subject to subsection (5), the report made pursuant to subsection (2) shall be reviewed by a qualified person at least once every three years to ensure that its assessment of the hazards with which it is concerned is still accurate.

If a confined space has not been entered in the three years preceding the time when the report referred to in subsection (4) should have been reviewed and no entry is scheduled, the report need not be reviewed until it becomes likely that a person will, in order to perform work for an employer, enter the confined space.

Section.Text: Every employer shall, after considering the report made pursuant to subsection 11.2(2),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in consultation with the work place committee or the health and safety representative, establish procedures, with the date on which they are established specified therein, that are to be followed by a person entering, exiting or occupying a confined space assessed pursuant to subsection 11.2(1), or a confined space that belongs to a class of confined spaces assessed pursuant to that subsection, and establish, where reasonably practicable, an entry permit system that provides for

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: specifying, in each case, the length of time for which an entry permit is valid, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: recording

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: the name of the person entering the confined space, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: the date and time of entry and the anticipated time of exit;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: specify the protection equipment referred to in Part XII that is to be used by every person who is granted access to the confined space by the employer;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: specify any insulated protection equipment and tools referred to in Part VIII that a person may need in the confined space; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: specify the protection equipment and emergency equipment to be used by a person who takes part in the rescue of a person from the confined space or in responding to other emergency situations in the confined space.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall, where a person is about to enter a confined space, appoint a qualified person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to verify, by means of tests, that compliance with the following specifications can be achieved during the period of time that the person will be in the confined space, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the concentration of any chemical agent or combination of chemical agents in the confined space to which the person is likely to be exposed will not result in the exposure of the person

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: to a concentration of that chemical agent or combination of chemical agents in excess of the value referred to in paragraph 10.19(1)(a), or

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: to a concentration of that chemical agent or combination of chemical agents in excess of the percentage set out in subsection 10.20(1), or in subsection 10.20(2) under the circumstances described in that subsection,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the concentration of airborne hazardous substances, other than chemical agents, in the confined space is not hazardous to the health or safety of the person, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the percentage of oxygen in the air in the confined space is not less than 18 per cent by volume and not more than 23 per cent by volume, at normal atmospheric pressure;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to verify that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any liquid in which the person could drown has been removed from the confined space,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any free-flowing solid in which the person may become entrapped has been removed from the confined space,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the entry of any liquid, free-flowing solid or hazardous substance into the confined space has been prevented by a secure means of disconnection or by the fitting of blank flanges,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: all electrical and mechanical equipment that may present a hazard to the person has been disconnected from its power source, real or residual, and has been locked out, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the opening for entry into and exit from the confined space is sufficient to allow the safe passage of a person using protection equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 11.5(1), to verify that the specifications set out in paragraph (a) are complied with during all times that a person is in the confined space.

Subsection.Text: The qualified person referred to in subsection (1) shall, in a signed and dated report to the employer, set out the results of the verification carried out in accordance with that subsection, including the test methods, the test results and a list of the test equipment used.
The employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where the report made pursuant to subsection (2) indicates that a person who has entered the confined space has been in danger, send the report to the work place committee or the health and safety representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in all other cases, make a written copy or a machine-readable version of the report available to the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Subsection.Text: Where conditions in a confined space or the nature of the work to be performed in a confined space is such that the specifications set out in paragraph 11.4(1)(a) cannot be complied with during all times that a person is in the confined space, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in consultation with the work place committee or the health and safety representative, establish emergency procedures to be followed in the event of an accident or other emergency in or near the confined space, which procedures shall specify the date on which they are established and provide for the immediate evacuation of the confined space when

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: an alarm is activated, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: there is any significant change in a concentration or percentage referred to in paragraph 11.4(1)(a) that would adversely affect the health or safety of a person in the confined space;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide the protection equipment referred to in paragraphs 11.3(b), (c) and (d) for each person who is about to enter the confined space;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that a qualified person trained in the entry and emergency procedures established pursuant to paragraph 11.3(a) and paragraph (a) is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in attendance outside the confined space, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in communication with the person inside the confined space;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: provide the qualified person referred to in paragraph (c) with a suitable alarm device for summoning assistance; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that two or more persons are in the immediate vicinity of the confined space to assist in the event of an accident or other emergency.

Subsection.Text: One of the persons referred to in paragraph (1)(e) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be trained in the emergency procedures established pursuant to paragraph (1)(a);
