Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be the holder of a basic first aid certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be provided with the protection equipment and emergency equipment referred to in paragraph 11.3(d).

Subsection.Text: The employer shall ensure that every person entering, exiting or occupying a confined space referred to in subsection (1) wears an appropriate safety harness that is securely attached to a lifeline that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is attached to a secure anchor outside the confined space;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is controlled by the qualified person referred to in paragraph (1)(c);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: protects the person from the hazard for which it is provided and does not in itself create a hazard; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is, where reasonably practicable, equipped with a mechanical lifting device.

Heading.TitleText: Record of Emergency Procedures and Equipment

Subsection.Text: When a person is about to enter a confined space under circumstances such that the specifications set out in paragraph 11.4(1)(a) cannot be complied with, the qualified person referred to in paragraph 11.5(1)(c) shall, in a signed and dated report to the employer,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: specify those procedures established pursuant to paragraph 11.5(1)(a) that are to be followed and the protection equipment, insulated protection equipment and tools and the emergency equipment that are to be used; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: specify any additional procedures and any other equipment that may be needed to ensure the health and safety of the person.

Subsection.Text: The report made pursuant to subsection (1) and any procedures specified therein shall be explained by the qualified person to every employee who is about to enter a confined space, and a copy of the report shall be signed and dated by any employee to whom the report and the procedures have been so explained, acknowledging by signature the reading of the report and the explanation thereof.
The employer shall provide

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: each person who is granted access to a confined space with the protection equipment specified pursuant to paragraph 11.3(b); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: each person who is to undertake rescue operations with the protection equipment and emergency equipment specified pursuant to paragraph 11.3(d).

Subsection.Text: The employer shall ensure that every person who enters, exits or occupies a confined space follows the procedures established pursuant to paragraph 11.3(a) and uses the protection equipment specified pursuant to paragraphs 11.3(b) and (c).

Section.Text: No person shall close off a confined space until a qualified person has verified that no person is inside it.

Subsection.Text: Unless a qualified person has determined that the work can be performed safely, hot work shall not be performed in a confined space that contains

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an explosive or flammable hazardous substance in a concentration in excess of 10 per cent of its lower explosive limit; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: oxygen in a concentration in excess of 23 per cent.

Subsection.Text: Where hot work is to be performed in a confined space that contains concentrations of flammable or explosive materials in excess of the concentration set out in paragraph (1)(a) or (b),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a qualified person shall patrol the area surrounding the confined space and maintain a fire-protection watch in that area until all fire hazard has passed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: fire extinguishers specified as emergency equipment pursuant to paragraph 11.3(d) shall be provided in the area referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: Where an airborne hazardous substance may be produced by hot work in a confined space, no person shall enter or occupy the confined space unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: section 11.10 is complied with; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person uses a respiratory protective device that meets the requirements of sections 12.2, 12.3 and 12.7.

Subsection.Text: Where ventilation equipment is used to maintain the concentration of a chemical agent or combination of chemical agents in a confined space at or below the concentration referred to in subparagraph 11.4(1)(a)(i), or to maintain the percentage of oxygen in the air of a confined space within the limits referred to in subparagraph 11.4(1)(a)(iii), the employer shall not grant access to the confined space to any person unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the ventilation equipment is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: equipped with an alarm that will, if the equipment fails, be activated automatically and be audible or visible to every person in the confined space, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: monitored by an employee who is in constant attendance at the equipment and who is in communication with the person or persons in the confined space; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the event of failure of the ventilation equipment, sufficient time will be available for the person to escape from the confined space before

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the concentration of the chemical agent or combination of chemical agents in the confined space exceeds the concentrations referred to in subparagraph 11.4(1)(a)(i), or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the percentage of oxygen in the air ceases to remain within the limits referred to in subparagraph 11.4(1)(a)(iii).

Subsection.Text: If the ventilation equipment fails to operate properly, the employee referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(ii) shall immediately inform the person or persons in the confined space of the failure of the equipment.
The employer shall provide every employee who is likely to enter a confined space with instruction and training in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures established pursuant to paragraphs 11.3(a) and 11.5(1)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the use of the protection equipment referred to in paragraphs 11.3(b), (c) and (d).

Subsection.Text: The employer shall ensure that no person enters a confined space unless the person is instructed in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures to be followed in accordance with paragraphs 11.3(a) and 11.5(1)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the use of the protection equipment referred to in paragraphs 11.3(b), (c) and (d).

Section.Text: The employer shall, at the employer’s place of business nearest to the work place in which the confined space is located, keep a written copy or a machine-readable version of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any report made pursuant to subsection 11.2(2) and the procedures established pursuant to paragraphs 11.3(a) and 11.5(1)(a) for a period of ten years after the date on which the qualified person signed the report or the procedures were established; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any report made pursuant to subsection 11.4(2)

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for a period of ten years after the date on which the qualified person signed the report where the verification procedures undertaken pursuant to paragraphs 11.4(1)(a) and (c) indicate that the specifications set out in subparagraphs 11.4(1)(a)(i) to (iii) were not complied with, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in every other case, for a period of two years after the date on which the qualified person signed the report.

Heading.Label: PART XII
Heading.TitleText: Safety Materials, Equipment, Devices and Clothing

Section.Text: Where

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is not reasonably practicable to eliminate or control a health or safety hazard in a work place within safe limits, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the use of protection equipment may prevent or reduce injury from that hazard,

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: every person granted access to the work place who is exposed to that hazard shall use the protection equipment prescribed by this Part.

Section.Text: All protection equipment referred to in section 12.1

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be designed to protect the person from the hazard for which it is provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall not in itself create a hazard.

Section.Text: All protection equipment provided by the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be maintained, inspected and tested by a qualified person; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where necessary to prevent a health hazard, be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition by a qualified person.

Section.Text: Where there is a hazard of head injury in a work place, protective headwear that meets the standards set out in CSA Standard Z94.1-M1977, Industrial Protective Headwear, the English version of which is dated April, 1977, as amended to September, 1982 and the French version of which is dated April, 1980 as amended to September, 1982, shall be used.

Subsection.Text: Where there is a hazard of a foot injury or electric shock through footwear in a work place, protective footwear that meets the standards set out in CSA Standard Z195-M1984, Protective Footwear, the English version of which is dated March, 1984 and the French version of which is dated December, 1984, shall be used.
Where there is a hazard of slipping in a work place, non-slip footwear shall be used.

Section.Text: Where there is a hazard of injury to the eyes, face, ears or front of the neck of an employee in a work place, the employer shall provide eye or face protectors that meet the standards set out in CSA Standard Z94.3-M1982, Industrial Eye and Face Protectors, the English version of which is dated May, 1982 and the French version of which is dated February, 1983.

Subsection.Text: Where there is a hazard of an airborne hazardous substance or an oxygen deficient atmosphere in a work place, the employer shall provide a respiratory protective device that is listed in the NIOSH Certified Equipment List published on February 13, 1998 by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, as amended from time to time, and that protects against the hazardous substance or oxygen deficiency, as the case may be.

A respiratory protective device referred to in subsection (1) shall be selected, fitted, cared for, used and maintained in accordance with the standards set out in CSA Standard Z94.4-M1982, Selection, Care and Use of Respirators, the English version of which is dated May, 1982, as amended to September, 1984 and the French version of which is dated March, 1983, as amended to September, 1984, excluding clauses 6.1.5, 10.3.3.1.2 and 10.3.3.4.2(c).
Where air is provided for the purpose of a respiratory protective device referred to in subsection (1),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air shall meet the standards set out in clauses 5.5.2 to 5.5.11 of CSA Standard CAN3-Z180.1-M85, Compressed Breathing Air and Systems, the English version of which is dated December 1985 and the French version of which is dated November 1987; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the system that supplies air shall be constructed, tested, operated and maintained in accordance with the CSA Standard referred to in paragraph (a).

Section.Text: Where a steel or aluminum self-contained breathing apparatus cylinder has a dent deeper than 1.5 mm and less than 50 mm in major diameter or shows evidence of deep isolated pitting, cracks or splits, the cylinder shall be removed from service until it has been shown to be safe for use by means of a hydrostatic test at a pressure equal to one and one-half times the maximum allowable working pressure.
Where there is a hazard of injury or disease to or through the skin in a work place, the employer shall provide to every person granted access to the work place

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a shield or screen;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a cream to protect the skin; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an appropriate body covering.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (1.1), every employer shall provide a fall-protection system to any person, other than an employee who is installing or removing a fall-protection system in accordance with the instructions referred to in subsection (5), who works

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from an unguarded structure or on a vehicle, at a height of more than 2.4 m above the nearest permanent safe level or above any moving parts of machinery or any other surface or thing that could cause injury to a person on contact;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from a temporary structure at a height of more than 6 m above a permanent safe level; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: from a ladder at a height of more than 2.4 m above the nearest permanent safe level where, because of the nature of the work, that person is unable to use at least one hand to hold onto the ladder.

Subsection.Text: Where an employee is required to work on a vehicle on which it is not reasonably practicable to provide a fall-protection system, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative,

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: perform a job safety analysis to eliminate or minimize the need for the employee to climb onto the vehicle or its load, and

Paragraph.Label: (ii)
Paragraph.Text: provide every employee who is likely to climb onto the vehicle or its load with training and instruction on the safe method of climbing onto and working on the vehicle or its load;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make a report in writing to the Minister setting out the reasons why it is not reasonably practicable to provide a fall-protection system and include the job safety analysis and a description of the training and instruction referred to in paragraph (a); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide a copy of the report referred to in paragraph (b) to the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Subsection.Text: The job safety analysis, training and instruction referred to in paragraph (1.1)(a) shall be reviewed every two years in consultation with the policy committee or, if there is no policy committee, the work place committee or the health and safety representative.
The components of a fall-protection system shall meet the following standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.1-1976, Fall-Arresting Safety Belts and Lanyards for the Construction and Mining Industries, the English version of which is dated November, 1976, as amended to May, 1979 and the French version of which is dated April, 1980;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.2-M1979, Fall-Arresting Devices, Personnel Lowering Devices and Life Lines, the English version of which is dated November, 1979 and the French version of which is dated October, 1983; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: CSA Standard Z259.3-M1978, Lineman’s Body Belt and Lineman’s Safety Strap, the English version of which is dated September, 1978, as amended to April, 1981 and the French version of which is dated April, 1980, as amended to April, 1981.

Subsection.Text: The anchor of a fall-protection system shall be capable of withstanding a force of 17.8 kN.
A fall-protection system that is used to arrest the fall of a person shall prevent that person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from being subjected to a peak fall arrest force greater than 8 kN; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from falling freely for more than 1.2 m.

Subsection.Text: Where an employee is about to install or remove a fall-protection system, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prepare written instructions for the safe installation or removal of the fall-protection system; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: keep a copy of the instructions readily available for the information of the employee.

Subsection.Text: Where, in a work place, there is a hazard of drowning, the employer shall provide every person granted access to the work place with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a life jacket or buoyancy device that meets the standards set out in the Canadian General Standards Board Standard

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: CAN2-65.7-M80, Life Jackets, Inherently Buoyant Type, dated April, 1980, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: 65-GP-11, Standard for: Personal Flotation Devices, dated October, 1972; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a safety net or a fall-protection system.

Subsection.Text: Where, in a work place, there is a hazard of drowning,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: emergency equipment shall be provided and held in readiness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is qualified to operate all the emergency equipment provided shall be available;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if appropriate, a powered boat shall be provided and held in readiness; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: written emergency procedures shall be prepared by the employer containing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a full description of the procedures to be followed and the responsibilities of all persons granted access to the work place, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of any emergency equipment.

Subsection.Text: Where a work place is a wharf, dock, pier, quay or other similar structure, a ladder that extends at least two rungs below water level shall be affixed to the face of the structure every 60 m along its length.

Section.Text: Loose clothing, long hair, dangling accessories, jewellery or other similar items that are likely to be hazardous to the health or safety of an employee in a work place shall not be worn unless they are so tied, covered or otherwise secured as to prevent the hazard.
Where an employee is regularly exposed to contact with moving vehicles during his work, he shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: wear a high-visibility vest or other similar clothing, or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be protected by a barricade

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: that is readily visible under all conditions of use.

Subsection.Text: A record of all protection equipment provided by the employer shall be kept by him in the work place in which the equipment is located for a period of two years after it ceases to be used.
The record referred to in subsection (1) shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the equipment and the date of its acquisition by the employer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date and result of each inspection and test of the equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the date and nature of any maintenance work performed on the equipment since its acquisition by the employer; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person who performed the inspection, test or maintenance of the equipment.

Subsection.Text: Every person granted access to the work place who uses protection equipment shall be instructed by the employer in the use of the equipment.
Every employee who uses protection equipment shall be instructed and trained in the use, operation and maintenance of the equipment.
Every person granted access to a work place shall be instructed in respect of the written emergency procedures referred to in paragraph 12.11(2)(d).
The instructions referred to in subsections (2) and (3) shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out in writing; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: kept by the employer readily available for examination by every person granted access to the work place.

Section.Text: Where an employee finds any defect in protection equipment that may render it unsafe for use, he shall report the defect to his employer as soon as possible.
An employer shall mark or tag as unsafe and remove from service any protection equipment used by his employees that has a defect that may render it unsafe for use.

In this Part, explosive actuated fastening tool means a tool that, by means of an explosive force, propels or discharges a fastener for the purpose of impinging it on, affixing it to or causing it to penetrate another object or material. (pistolet de scellement à cartouches explosives)

Heading.TitleText: Design, Construction, Operation and Use of Tools

Section.Text: The exterior surface of any tool used by an employee in a fire hazard area shall be made of non-sparking material.

All portable electric tools used by employees shall meet the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN C22.2 No. 71.1-M89, Portable Electric Tools, the English version of which is dated September 1989 and the French version of which is dated February 1991.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), all portable electric tools used by employees shall be grounded.
Subsection (1) does not apply to tools that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are powered by a self-contained battery;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have a protective system of double insulation; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are used in a location where reliable grounding cannot be obtained if the tools are supplied from a double insulated portable ground fault circuit interrupter of the class A type that meets the standards set out in CSA Standard C22.2 No. 144-1977, Ground Fault Circuit Interrupters, dated March, 1977.

Section.Text: All portable electric tools used by employees in a fire hazard area shall be marked as appropriate for use or designed for use in the area of that hazard.
Where an air hose is connected to a portable air-powered tool used by an employee, a restraining device shall be attached

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: where an employee may be injured by the tool falling, to the tool; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to all hose connections, in order to prevent injury to an employee in the event of an accidental disconnection of a hose.

Subsection.Text: All explosive actuated fastening tools used by employees shall meet the standards set out in CSA Standard Z166-1975, Explosive Actuated Fastening Tools, dated June, 1975.
No employee shall operate an explosive actuated fastening tool unless authorized to do so by his employer.
Every employee who operates an explosive actuated fastening tool shall operate it in accordance with the CSA Standard referred to in subsection (1).

Section.Text: All chain saws used by employees shall meet the standards set out in CSA Standard CAN3-Z62.1-M85, Chain Saws, dated February, 1985.
Where an employee finds any defect in a tool or machine that may render it unsafe for use, he shall report the defect to his employer as soon as possible.
An employer shall mark or tag as unsafe and remove from service any tool or machine used by his employees that has a defect that may render it unsafe for use.

Every employee shall be instructed and trained by a qualified person appointed by his employer in the safe and proper inspection, maintenance and use of all tools and machinery that he is required to use.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall maintain a manual of operating instructions for each type of portable electric tool, portable air-powered tool, explosive actuated fastening tool and machine used by his employees.
A manual referred to in subsection (1) shall be kept by the employer readily available for examination by an employee who is required to use the tool or machine to which the manual applies.

Every machine that has exposed moving, rotating, electrically charged or hot parts or that processes, transports or handles material that constitutes a hazard to an employee shall be equipped with a machine guard that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevents the employee or any part of his body from coming into contact with the parts or material;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevents access by the employee to the area of exposure to the hazard during the operation of the machine; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: makes the machine inoperative if the employee or any part of his clothing is in or near a part of the machine that is likely to cause injury.

Subsection.Text: To the extent that is reasonably practicable, a machine guard referred to in subsection (1) shall not be removable.
A machine guard shall be so constructed, installed and maintained that it meets the requirements of subsection (1).

Heading.TitleText: Use, Operation, Repair and Maintenance of Machine Guards

Section.Text: Machine guards shall be operated, maintained and repaired by a qualified person.
Subject to section 13.16, where a machine guard is installed on a machine, no person shall use or operate the machine unless the machine guard is in its proper position.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), where it is necessary to remove a machine guard from a machine in order to perform repair or maintenance work on the machine, no person shall perform the repair or maintenance work unless the machine has been locked out in accordance with a written lock out procedure provided by the employer.
Where it is not reasonably practicable to lock out a machine referred to in subsection (1) in order to perform repair or maintenance work on the machine, the work may be performed if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person performing the work follows written instructions provided by the employer that will ensure that any hazard to that person is not significantly greater than it would be if the machine had been locked out; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person performing the work

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: obtains a written authorization from the employer each time the work is performed, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: performs the work under the direct supervision of a qualified person.

Section.Text: A copy of the instructions referred to in section 13.16 shall be kept readily available by the employer for the information of persons who perform repair and maintenance work on his machines.
Abrasive wheels shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: used only on machines equipped with machine guards,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: mounted between flanges, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: operated

ContinuedSectionSubsection.Text: in accordance with sections 4 to 6 of CSA Standard B173.5-1979, Safety Requirements for the Use, Care and Protection of Abrasive Wheels, dated February, 1979.

Section.Text: A bench grinder shall be equipped with a work rest or other device that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevents the work piece from jamming between the abrasive wheel and the wheel guard; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: does not make contact with the abrasive wheel at any time.

Section.Text: Equipment used in the mechanical transmission of power shall be guarded in accordance with sections 7 to 10 of ANSI Standard ANSI B15.1-1972, Safety Standard for Mechanical Power Transmission Apparatus, dated July, 1972.
Woodworking machinery shall be guarded in accordance with clause 3.3 of CSA Standard Z114-M1977, Safety Code for the Woodworking Industry, dated March, 1977.
Punch presses shall meet the standards set out in CSA Standard Z142-1976, Code for the Guarding of Punch Presses at Point of Operation, dated February, 1976.
In this Part,

Definition.Text: materials handling equipment means equipment, including its supporting structures, auxiliary equipment and rigging devices, used to transport, lift, move or position persons, materials, goods or things and includes mobile equipment used to lift, hoist or position persons, but does not include an elevating device that is permanently installed in a building; (appareil de manutention)
motorized hand-rider truck means motorized materials handling equipment that is designed to be controlled by a walking or onboard operator; (chariot à conducteur porté ou accompagnant)

operator means a person who controls the operation of motorized or manual materials handling equipment and who has received or is receiving instruction and training in respect of the procedures referred to in subsection 14.23(1) or (3), as the case may be; (opérateur)

safe working load means the maximum load that the motorized or manual materials handling equipment is designed and constructed to handle or support safely under particular operating conditions; (charge de travail admissible)
signaller means a person instructed by an employer to direct, by means of visual or auditory signals, the safe movement and operation of motorized materials handling equipment. (signaleur)

Section.Text: This Part does not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection 14.4(4), the use and operation of motor vehicles on public roads;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the use and operation of tackle regulated pursuant to the Canada Shipping Act in the loading or unloading of ships; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the underground workings of mines.

Subsection.Text: Motorized and manual materials handling equipment shall, to the extent that is reasonably practicable, be so designed and constructed that if there is a failure of any part of the materials handling equipment, that failure will not result in loss of control of the materials handling equipment or create a hazardous condition.

All glass and other transparent materials used in doors, windows and other parts of motorized materials handling equipment shall be of a type that does not shatter into sharp or dangerous pieces on impact.

Subject to subsection 14.51(1), an employer shall ensure that the onboard operator’s compartment in, or position on, motorized materials handling equipment provides adequate adjustability of range to accommodate properly the operator for the work that is required to be done.

Where motorized materials handling equipment is used under such circumstances that the onboard operator of the equipment may be struck by a falling object or shifting load, the employer shall equip the motorized materials handling equipment with a protective structure of such a design, construction and strength that it will, under all foreseeable conditions, prevent the penetration of the object or load into the compartment or position occupied by the operator.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a motorized hand-rider truck unless there is a likelihood of its operator being struck by a falling object or a shifting load.
A protective structure referred to in subsection (1) shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: constructed of non-combustible or fire-resistant material; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: designed to permit quick exit from the motorized materials handling equipment in an emergency.

Subsection.Text: Where there is a likelihood that materials, goods or things will shift and endanger employees in a motor vehicle acquired after July 1, 1995 and having a gross vehicle weight of less than 4,500 kg, the employer shall install a bulkhead or other means to protect the employees.

Section.Text: Where during the loading or unloading of motorized materials handling equipment the load will pass over the operator’s compartment or position, the operator shall not occupy that compartment in, or position on, the equipment unless it is equipped with a protective structure required under section 14.4.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection 14.51(2), where motorized materials handling equipment is used in circumstances where it may turn over, it shall be fitted with a rollover protection device that meets the standards set out in CSA Standard B352-M1980, Rollover Protective Structures (ROPS) for Agricultural, Construction, Earthmoving, Forestry, Industrial, and Mining Machines, the English version of which is dated September 1980 and the French version of which is dated April 1991, as amended from time to time, and that will prevent the operator of the motorized materials handling equipment from being trapped or crushed under the equipment if it does turn over.
Subject to subsection 14.51(1), all motorized materials handling equipment used in circumstances described in subsection (1) shall be fitted with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: seat-belts; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: restraining devices preventing the displacement of the battery if the equipment turns over.

Section.Text: Where motorized materials handling equipment is used under conditions where a seat-belt or shoulder-type strap restraining device is likely to contribute to the safety of the operator or passengers, the materials handling equipment shall be equipped with such a belt or device.

Subsection.Text: If a fuel tank, compressed gas cylinder or other container or any associated assembly mounted on motorized materials handling equipment contains a hazardous substance, the employer shall ensure that the tank, cylinder, container or assembly is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: so located or guarded that under all conditions it is not hazardous to the health or safety of an employee who is required to operate or ride on the materials handling equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: connected to fuel overflow and vent pipes that are so located that fuel spills and vapours cannot be

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: ignited by hot exhaust pipes or other hot or sparking parts, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: hazardous to the health or safety of an employee who is required to operate or ride on the materials handling equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: labelled on its servicing caps or covers as to its contents.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection 14.51(2), the installation, operation and maintenance of propane fuelled motorized materials handling equipment shall be in accordance with the Canadian Gas Association Standard CAN/CGA-B149.2-M91, Propane Installation Code, dated 1991, as amended from time to time.

Motorized materials handling equipment that is regularly used outdoors shall be fitted with a roof or other structure that will protect the operator from exposure to any weather condition that is likely to be hazardous to the operator’s health or safety.

Where the heat produced by motorized materials handling equipment results in a temperature above 26°C in the compartment or position occupied by that operator, the area shall be protected from the heat by an insulated barrier.

Section.Text: Subject to subsection 14.51(1), an employer shall ensure that all motorized materials handling equipment in use is designed and constructed so that any employee required to operate or ride on it will not be injured or its control will not be impaired by any vibration, jolting or uneven movement of the materials handling equipment.

Subject to subsection 14.51(1), the design and arrangement of displays and controls and the general design and layout of the operator’s compartment or position on all motorized materials handling equipment shall not hinder or prevent its operator from operating the equipment and shall, where reasonably practicable, maximize its operator’s ability to collect, comprehend and process information necessary for the safe use of the equipment.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall equip motorized materials handling equipment that is used for transporting or handling flammable substances with a dry chemical fire extinguisher.
A fire extinguisher referred to in subsection (1) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: have not less than a 5 B, C rating as defined in the National Fire Code;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: meet the standards set out in section 6.2 of the National Fire Code; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be so located that it is readily accessible to the operator of the motorized materials handling equipment while the operator is in the operating position.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to motorized materials handling equipment that is used exclusively within a building that has the fire extinguishers required by Part XVII.
Subject to subsection 14.51(1), an employer shall ensure that all motorized materials handling equipment has a safe means of entering and exiting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the work area of the operator; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other place on the equipment to which an employee requires regular access.

Subsection.Text: A safe means referred to in subsection (1) shall take into account the employee’s body dimensions while wearing personal protective equipment and shall not require the employee to jump from the motorized materials handling equipment.

Subject to subsection (2), where motorized materials handling equipment is used by an employee in a work place at night or at any time when the level of lighting within the work place is less than 10 lx, the materials handling equipment shall be fitted with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: warning lights on the front and rear that are visible from a distance of not less than 100 m; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: lighting that ensures the safe operation of the equipment.

Subsection.Text: No motorized materials handling equipment shall be used at night on a route that is used by other vehicles unless it is fitted with such lights as are required under the laws of the province in which the equipment is used.

Section.Text: All motorized materials handling equipment shall be fitted with braking, steering and other control systems that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are capable of controlling and stopping its movement and that of any hoist, bucket or other part of the equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respond reliably and quickly to moderate effort on the part of the employee controlling them.

Subsection.Text: Motorized materials handling equipment that is used in an area occupied by employees and that travels

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: forward at speeds in excess of 8 km/h shall be fitted with a horn or other similar audible warning device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in reverse shall, subject to subsection 14.51(1), be fitted with a horn or other similar audible warning device that automatically operates while it travels in reverse.

Subsection.Text: Where an audible warning device referred to in subsection (1) cannot be clearly heard above the noise of the motorized materials handling equipment and any surrounding noise, does not allow enough time for a person to avoid the danger in question or does not otherwise provide adequate warning, other visual, audible or tactile warning devices or methods shall be used so that adequate warning is provided.

Where the use of an audible warning device referred to in subsection (1) would result in night-time noise levels in excess of those allowed by a municipal by-law applicable where the motorized material handling equipment is used, visual or tactile warning devices or methods may be used at night if such devices or methods provide an adequate warning.

Section.Text: Where motorized materials handling equipment cannot be operated safely in reverse unless it is fitted with sufficient rear-view mirrors, it shall be so fitted.

Subject to subsection 14.51(2), the design, construction, operation and maintenance of guided industrial vehicles shall meet the standards set out in the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard ASME B56.5-1993, Safety Standard for Guided Industrial Vehicles and Automated Functions of Manned Industrial Vehicles, dated 1993, as amended from time to time.

Subject to subsection 14.51(2), the design, construction, operation and maintenance of each conveyor, cableway or other similar motorized materials handling equipment shall meet the standards set out in the American Society of Mechanical Engineers Standard ASME B20.1-1993, Safety Standard for Conveyors and Related Equipment, dated 1993, as amended from time to time.

Subsection.Text: Before motorized or manual materials handling equipment is used for the first time in a work place, the employer shall set out in writing instructions on the inspection, testing and maintenance of that materials handling equipment.
Instructions referred to in subsection (1) shall specify the nature and frequency of inspections, testing and maintenance.
The inspection, testing and maintenance referred to in subsection (1) shall be performed by a qualified person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: complies with the instructions referred to in that subsection; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: makes and signs a report of each inspection, test or maintenance work performed by the qualified person.

Subsection.Text: A report referred to in paragraph (3)(b) shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: include the date of the inspection, testing or maintenance performed by the qualified person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify the materials handling equipment that was inspected, tested or maintained; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: set out the safety observations of the qualified person.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall keep at the work place at which the motorized or manual materials handling equipment is located a copy of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the instructions referred to in subsection (1) for as long as the materials handling equipment is in use; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the report referred to in paragraph (3)(b) for a period of one year after the report is signed.

Section.Text: Mobile cranes shall be inspected, tested and maintained in accordance with the requirements of section 5 of CSA Standard Z150-1974, Safety Code for Mobile Cranes, dated 1974, and its supplement Z150S1-1977 entitled Supplement 1-1977 to CSA Standard Z150-1974 Safety Code for Mobile Cranes, published in 1977.

Subsection.Text: Every employer whose employees maintain or repair motorized materials handling equipment equipped with split rim wheels shall set out in writing instructions for those employees on the maintenance and repair of those wheels.

Instructions referred to in subsection (1) shall include instructions on training, inspection, installation, guarding, compatibility of parts used and repairs relating to the assembling and disassembling of split rim wheels.

The employer shall keep a copy of the instructions referred to in subsection (1) at the work place in which the motorized materials handling equipment referred to in that subsection is kept for as long as the equipment is in use.
Subject to subsection (2), every employer shall ensure that every operator of motorized materials handling equipment has been instructed and trained in the procedures to be followed for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its inspection;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its fuelling; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its safe and proper use, in accordance with any instructions provided by the manufacturer and taking into account the conditions of the work place in which the operator will operate the materials handling equipment.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to an operator who, under the direct supervision of a qualified person, is being instructed and trained to use motorized materials handling equipment or on the matters referred to in that subsection.
An employer shall ensure that every operator of manual materials handling equipment receives on-the-job training by a qualified person on the procedures to be followed for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its inspection; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its safe and proper use, in accordance with any instructions of the manufacturer and taking into account the conditions of the work place in which the operator will operate the manual materials handling equipment and the operator’s physical capabilities.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall keep a written record, in respect of an operator, of any instruction or training referred to in subsection (1) for as long as the operator remains in the employer’s employment.

Section.Text: No employer shall require an employee to operate motorized or manual materials handling equipment unless the employee

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is an operator; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where the laws of the province in which the equipment is operated require an operator’s licence, possesses an operator’s licence issued by any province.

Section.Text: No employer shall require an operator to operate motorized materials handling equipment unless the operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is directed by a signaller; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has an unobstructed view of the area in which the equipment is to be operated.

Subsection.Text: Every employer who wishes to use signals to direct the movement of motorized materials handling equipment shall establish a single code of signals to be used by signallers in all of the employer’s work places.
Subject to subsection (3), signals from the code referred to in subsection (1) shall be given by a signaller, who may use only those signals.
A signal to stop given in an emergency by any person granted access to the work place by the employer shall be obeyed by an operator.
No signaller shall perform duties other than signalling while the motorized materials handling equipment under the signaller’s direction is in operation.

Where any movement of motorized materials handling equipment that is directed by a signaller poses a risk to the safety of any person, the signaller shall not give the signal to move until that person is warned of, or protected from, the risk.
Where the operator of any motorized materials handling equipment does not understand a signal, the operator shall consider that signal to be a stop signal.

Subject to subsection (2), where the use by a signaller of visual signals will not be an effective means of communication, the employer shall provide the signaller and the operator with a telephone, radio or other audible signalling device.
No radio transmitting equipment shall be used in a work place for the transmission of signals where such use may activate electric blasting equipment in that place.

Where a signalling device referred to in subsection (1) functions unreliably or improperly and the operation of any motorized materials handling equipment cannot be safely directed by another means of signalling, use of the motorized materials handling equipment shall be discontinued until the signalling device is repaired or replaced.
Where an employee finds a defect in radio transmitting signalling equipment that may render it unsafe for use, the employee shall report the defect to the employer as soon as possible.

Section.Text: No employee shall operate and no employer shall permit an employee to operate motorized materials handling equipment on a ramp with a gradient in excess of the lesser of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the gradient that is recommended as safe by the manufacturer of the motorized materials handling equipment, either loaded or unloaded, as applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: such gradient as a qualified person determines to be safe, having regard to the mechanical condition of the motorized materials handling equipment and its load and traction.

Subsection.Text: Motorized or manual materials handling equipment that creates a health or safety hazard owing to a defect in the materials handling equipment shall be taken out of service until it has been repaired or modified by a qualified person.

Subject to subsection (3), any repair, modification or replacement of a part of any motorized or manual materials handling equipment shall at least maintain the safety factor of the materials handling equipment or part.

If a part of less strength or quality than the original part is used in the repair, modification or replacement of a part of any motorized or manual materials handling equipment, the employer shall restrict the use of the materials handling equipment to such loading and use as will ensure the retention of the original safety factor of the equipment or part.
An employer shall keep a record of any repair or modification referred to in subsection (1) and of any restriction on use imposed pursuant to subsection (3).

Motorized or manual materials handling equipment shall not be used for transporting an employee and no employee shall so use the equipment unless the equipment is specifically designed for that purpose.

Motorized or manual materials handling equipment shall not be used for hoisting or positioning an employee, unless the equipment is equipped with a platform, bucket or basket designed for those purposes.
Any motorized materials handling equipment that is normally used for transporting employees from place to place in a work place shall be equipped with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a mechanical parking brake; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a hydraulic or pneumatic braking system.

Heading.TitleText: Loading, Unloading and Maintenance While in Motion

Section.Text: No materials, goods or things shall be picked up from, or placed on, any motorized or manual materials handling equipment while the equipment is in motion unless the equipment is specifically designed for that purpose.
Except in the case of an emergency, no employee shall get on or off of motorized or manual materials handling equipment while it is in motion.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), no repair, maintenance or cleaning work shall be performed on motorized or manual materials handling equipment while the materials handling equipment is in use.

Fixed parts of motorized or manual materials handling equipment may be repaired, maintained or cleaned while the materials handling equipment is being used if the parts are so isolated or guarded that the use of the materials handling equipment does not present a risk to the safety of the employee performing the repair, maintenance or cleaning work.

Where motorized or manual materials handling equipment is travelling with a raised or suspended load, its operator shall ensure that the load is carried as close to the ground or floor as the situation permits and shall not in any case transport the load at or beyond the point at which the loaded equipment becomes unstable.

Any load, other than bulk materials, that would likely slide on or fall from motorized or manual materials handling equipment resulting in a hazardous condition shall be secured to prevent such movement.

Section.Text: Tools, tool boxes or spare parts that are carried on motorized or manual materials handling equipment shall be securely stored.

The floor, cab and other occupied parts of motorized materials handling equipment shall be kept free of any grease, oil, materials, tools, equipment or other hazards that may cause an employee to slip or trip or may create a fire hazard or otherwise interfere with the safe operation of the equipment.

Subsection.Text: No motorized or manual materials handling equipment shall be parked in a corridor, aisle, doorway or other place where it may interfere with the safe movement of persons, materials, goods or things.

Where motorized or manual materials handling equipment is required to enter or exit a vehicle other than a railway car to load or unload materials, goods or things to or from the vehicle, the vehicle shall be immobilized and secured against accidental movement, by means additional to the vehicle’s braking system.

Where motorized or manual materials handling equipment is required to enter or exit a railway car to load or unload materials, goods or things to or from the railway car, the railway car shall be immobilized.
Any motorized materials handling equipment that is left unattended shall be immobilized against accidental movement, by applying a parking brake or other braking device.
In this section, materials handling area means an area within which materials handling equipment may create a hazard to any person.
An employer shall cause warning signs to be posted, or a signaller to be in control, at the approaches to any materials handling area while materials handling operations are in progress.
Only the following persons may enter a materials handling area while materials handling operations are in progress:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an employee whose presence in the materials handling area is essential to the conduct, supervision or safety of the materials handling operations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a person who has been authorized by the employer to be in the materials handling area while materials handling operations are in progress.

Subsection.Text: If any person other than a person referred to in subsection (3) enters a materials handling area, the employer shall cause the materials handling operations in the immediate vicinity of the unauthorized person to be immediately discontinued and to remain discontinued until the person has left that materials handling area.

Subject to subsection (2), no motorized or manual materials handling equipment shall be used in an area in which it may contact an electrical cable, a pipeline containing a hazardous substance or any other hazard known to the employer, unless the employer has informed the operator of the presence and location of the hazard and of the safety clearance that the operator must maintain with respect to the hazard.

Where an employer is unable to determine with reasonable certainty the location of an electrical cable or a pipeline containing a hazardous substance, the electrical cable shall be de-energized or the pipeline shut down and drained before any activity involving the use of motorized materials handling equipment commences within the area of possible contact with the electrical cable or the pipeline.

Section.Text: Where rear-dumping motorized materials handling equipment is used to discharge a load at the edge of a sudden drop in grade level that may cause the equipment to tip and in order to prevent the motorized materials handling equipment from being backed over the edge,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a bumping block shall be used; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a signaller shall give directions to the operator of the equipment.

Section.Text: Where motorized materials handling equipment is fuelled in a work place, a qualified person shall do the fuelling in accordance with procedures referred to in subsection 14.23(1) in a place that is well ventilated so that the vapours from the fuel will be dissipated quickly.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall, with respect to the use and maintenance of any rope, sling or chain or any attachment or fitting thereon used by an employee, adopt and implement the recommendations set out in Chapter 10 of the Accident Prevention Manual for Business and Industry, 10th edition, published by the National Safety Council of the United States, dated 1992.
Subsection (1) does not apply to ropes, slings or chains or to any attachments or fittings thereon that comply with the requirements of the Tackle Regulations.
Motorized or manual materials handling equipment shall be legibly marked with sufficient information so as to enable the operator to determine its safe working load.
No motorized or manual materials handling equipment shall be used with a load that exceeds its safe working load.

An employer shall provide a clearly marked pathway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and persons using wheelchairs and other similar devices that is not less than 750 mm wide along one side of an aisle, corridor or other course of travel that is found in a work place and that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is a principal traffic route for mobile equipment, pedestrians and persons using wheelchairs and other similar devices; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: exceeds 15 m in length.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply where a signaller or traffic lights are provided for the purpose of controlling traffic and protecting persons.

Where an aisle, corridor or other course of travel that is a principal traffic route in a work place intersects with another route, an employer shall cause warning signs marked with the words “DANGEROUS INTERSECTION — CROISEMENT DANGEREUX”, in letters not less than 50 mm in height on a contrasting background, to be posted along the approaches to the intersection.

At blind corners, mirrors shall be installed that permit a mobile equipment operator to see a pedestrian, a person using a wheelchair or other similar device, a vehicle or mobile equipment approaching the blind corner.
In any passageway that is regularly travelled by motorized or manual materials handling equipment, the employer shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an overhead clearance is at least 150 mm above

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: that part of the materials handling equipment or its load that is the highest when the materials handling equipment is in its highest normal operating position at the point of clearance, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the top of the head of the operator or any other employee required to ride on the materials handling equipment when occupying the highest normal position for the operator or employee at the point of clearance; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a side clearance is sufficiently wide to permit the motorized or manual materials handling equipment and its load to be manoeuvred safely by an operator, but in no case less than 150 mm on each side measured from the furthest projecting part of the equipment or its load, when the equipment is being operated in a normal manner.

Subsection.Text: Where an overhead clearance measured in accordance with subparagraph (l)(a)(i) or (ii) is less than 300 mm, the employer shall cause

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the top of the doorway or object that restricts the clearance to be marked with a distinguishing colour or mark; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the height of the passageway in metres to be shown near the top of the passageway in letters that are not less than 50 mm in height and are on a contrasting background.

Subsection.Text: Subparagraph (l)(a)(i) and subsection (2) do not apply in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: motorized materials handling equipment whose course of travel is controlled by fixed rails or guides;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that portion of the route of any motorized or manual materials handling equipment that is inside a railway car, truck or trailer truck, including the warehouse doorway leading directly to it; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a load the nature of which precludes compliance with that subparagraph or subsection if precautions are taken to prevent contact with objects that may restrict the movement of the equipment.

Subsection.Text: Where, because of the weight, size, shape, toxicity or other characteristic of materials, goods or things, the manual handling of materials, goods or things may be hazardous to the health or safety of an employee, the employer shall issue instructions that the materials, goods or things shall, where reasonably practicable, not be handled manually.

For the purposes of subsection (1), the employer shall take into account the frequency and duration of manual lifting and the distances and terrain over which an object is to be manually lifted or carried in deciding whether the manual handling of the materials, goods or things may be hazardous to the health or safety of an employee.

Section.Text: No employer shall require an employee who is an office worker and whose primary tasks do not include manual lifting or carrying to manually lift or carry materials, goods or things in excess of 23 kg.
Where an employee is required manually to lift or carry loads weighing in excess of 10 kg, the employer shall instruct and train the employee

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in a safe method of lifting and carrying the loads that will minimize the stress on the body; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a work procedure appropriate to the employee’s physical condition and the conditions of the work place.

Section.Text: Where an employee is required manually to lift or carry loads weighing in excess of 45 kg, the employer shall give instructions to the employee in accordance with section 14.48 that are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: set out in writing;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: readily available to the employee; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: kept by the employer for a period of two years after they cease to apply.

Subsection.Text: All materials, goods and things shall be stored in the work place in such a manner that the maximum safe load carrying capacity of the floor or other supporting structures is not exceeded.

All materials, goods or things shall be stored and placed in such a manner that employees are not required manually to lift materials, goods or things in a manner that would lead to overextension of or excessive strain on the body.
All materials, goods or things shall be stored in a manner so that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: light in the storage area is not reduced below the levels required by Part VI;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is no obstruction or encroachment of passageways, traffic lanes or exits;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the safe operation of motorized or manual materials handling equipment is not impeded;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the ready access to or the operation of fire fighting equipment is not obstructed;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the operation of fixed fire protection equipment is not interfered with; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: there is no risk to the health or safety of any employee.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), motorized materials handling equipment that is in use at the time this amendment comes into force, and that meets the requirements of this Part as it read immediately before the coming into force of this amendment, is exempt from having to comply with the amendment as long as the motorized materials handling equipment continues to meet those requirements.

Subject to subsection (3), motorized or manual materials handling equipment that is in use at the time an amendment to a standard or code incorporated by subsection 14.6(1) or 14.8(2) or section 14.18 or 14.19 comes into force and that complies with the standard or code as it read immediately before the coming into force of the amendment, is exempt from having to comply with the amendment as long as the motorized or manual materials handling equipment continues to meet that standard or code.
An employer shall ensure that, wherever reasonably practicable, equipment referred to in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subsection (1) meets the requirements of subsection 14.3(3) or 14.6(2), section 14.10, 14.11 or 14.13 or paragraph 14.16(1)(b); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subsection (2) complies with an amendment referred to in that subsection.

Subsection.Text: If it is not reasonably practicable for materials handling equipment in use at the time an amendment referred to in subsection (1) or (2) comes into force to comply with the amendment, the employer whose employees use the equipment shall notify the work place committee or the health and safety representative of the non-compliance.

Heading.Label: PART XV
Heading.TitleText: Hazardous Occurrence Investigation, Recording and Reporting

Section.Text: In this Part,

Definition.Text: disabling injury means an employment injury or an occupational disease that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prevents an employee from reporting for work or from effectively performing all the duties connected with the employee’s regular work on any day subsequent to the day on which the injury or disease occurred, whether or not that subsequent day is a working day for that employee,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: results in the loss by an employee of a body member or part thereof or in the complete loss of the usefulness of a body member or part thereof, or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: results in the permanent impairment of a body function of an employee; (blessure invalidante)

Definition.Text: district office, in respect of a work place, means the office of the Department of Employment and Social Development that is responsible for the HRSDC Labour Program and that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: closest to the work place, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any of the Department’s administrative regions in which the work place is situated; (bureau de district)

Definition.Text: minor injury means an employment injury or an occupational disease for which medical treatment is provided and excludes a disabling injury. (blessure légère)

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), this Part does not apply in respect of employees employed in a coal mine or in an underground portion of any other type of mine.
Section 15.10 applies in respect of employees employed in a coal mine.

Section.Text: Where an employee becomes aware of an accident or other occurrence arising in the course of or in connection with the employee’s work that has caused or is likely to cause injury to that employee or to any other person, the employee shall, without delay, report the accident or other occurrence to his employer, orally or in writing.

Subsection.Text: Where an employer becomes aware of an accident, occupational disease or other hazardous occurrence affecting any of his employees in the course of employment, the employer shall, without delay,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appoint a qualified person to carry out an investigation of the hazardous occurrence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify the work place committee or the health and safety representative of the hazardous occurrence and of the name of the person appointed to investigate it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: take necessary measures to prevent a recurrence of the hazardous occurrence.

Subsection.Text: Where the hazardous occurrence referred to in subsection (1) is an accident involving a motor vehicle on a public road that is investigated by a police authority, the investigation referred to in paragraph (1)(a) shall be carried out by obtaining from the appropriate police authority a copy of its report respecting the accident.
As soon as possible after receipt of the report referred to in subsection (2), the employer shall provide a copy thereof to the work place committee or the health and safety representative.

Section.Text: The employer shall report to the Minister, by telephone or telex, the date, time, location and nature of any accident, occupational disease or other hazardous occurrence referred to in section 15.4 that had one of the following results, as soon as feasible but not later than 24 hours after becoming aware of that result:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the death of an employee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a disabling injury to two or more employees;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the loss by an employee of a body member or a part thereof or the complete loss of the usefulness of a body member or a part thereof;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the permanent impairment of a body function of an employee;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an explosion;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: damage to a boiler or pressure vessel that results in fire or the rupture of the boiler or pressure vessel; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any damage to an elevating device that renders it unserviceable, or a free fall of an elevating device.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall, within 72 hours after a hazardous occurrence referred to in paragraph 15.5(f) or (g), record in writing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the hazardous occurrence and the date, time and location of the occurrence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the causes of the occurrence; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the corrective measures taken or the reason for not taking corrective measures.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall, without delay, submit a copy of the record referred to in subsection (1) to the work place committee or the health and safety representative.
Every employer shall keep a record of each minor injury of which the employer is aware that affects any employee in the course of employment.
A record kept pursuant to subsection (1) shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and location of the occurrence that resulted in the minor injury;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the employee affected;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a brief description of the minor injury; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the causes of the minor injury.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall make a report in writing, without delay, in the form set out in Schedule I to this Part setting out the information required by that form, including the results of the investigation referred to in paragraph 15.4(1)(a), where that investigation discloses that the hazardous occurrence resulted in any one of the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a disabling injury to an employee;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an electric shock, toxic atmosphere or oxygen deficient atmosphere that caused an employee to lose consciousness;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the implementation of rescue, revival or other similar emergency procedures; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a fire or an explosion.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall submit a copy of the report referred to in subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: without delay, to the work place committee or the health and safety representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: within 14 days after the hazardous occurrence, to the Minister.

Section.Text: If an accident referred to in subsection 15.4(2) results in a circumstance referred to in subsection 15.8(1), the employer shall, within 14 days after the receipt of the police report of the accident, submit a copy of that report to the Minister.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall, not later than March 1 in each year, submit to the Minister a written report setting out the number of accidents, occupational diseases and other hazardous occurrences of which the employer is aware affecting any employee in the course of employment during the 12 month period ending on December 31 of the preceding year.

The report shall be in the form set out in Schedule II to this Part, contain the information required by that form and be accompanied by a copy of any report made in accordance with subsection 19.8(1).

Section.Text: Every employer shall keep a copy of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: each report submitted under section 15.9 or subsection 15.10(1) for a period of 10 years following the submission of the report to the Minister; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the record or report referred to in subsection 15.6(1), 15.7(1) or 15.8(1) for a period of 10 years following the hazardous occurrence.
