Section.Text: The definitions in this section apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: ambulance response time means the time required for an ambulance with trained personnel and emergency medical equipment to reach the workplace from the nearest point of dispatch under normal travel conditions. (délai d’intervention ambulancière)
first aid attendant means a holder of a valid basic or standard first aid certificate. (secouriste)
first aid station means a place, other than a first aid room, at which first aid supplies or equipment are stored. (poste de secours)

health unit means a facility that is under the charge of a physician or a person who is registered as a registered nurse under the laws of any province, and that, if it is under the control of the employer, meets the minimum requirements of a first aid room contained in this Part. (service de santé)
medical treatment facility means a hospital, medical clinic or physician’s office, at which emergency medical treatment can be dispensed. (installation de traitement médical)
remote workplace means a workplace for which the ambulance response time is more than two hours. (lieu de travail isolé)

standard first aid certificate means the certificate issued by either a qualified person or the organization that developed the training, as the case may be, for successful completion of a two-day first aid course; (certificat de secourisme général)

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall establish, and keep up to date, written instructions that provide for the prompt rendering of first aid to an employee for an injury, an occupational disease or an illness.
The employer shall keep a copy of the instructions available at all times for consultation by employees.
At every workplace at which six or more employees are working at any time, the employer shall ensure that there is a first aid attendant.
At every remote workplace at which two or more employees are working at any time, the employer shall ensure that there is a first aid attendant.
At every workplace at which an employee is working on live high voltage electrical equipment, the employer shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a first aid attendant is available; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one of the employees has the training necessary to provide resuscitation by mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, cardiopulmonary resuscitation or an equivalent direct method.

Subsection.Text: At every workplace that is required to have a first aid attendant, the employer shall ensure that the first aid attendant at the workplace is qualified by having at least

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the workplace is an office workplace for which the ambulance response time is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: up to two hours, a basic first aid certificate, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: more than two hours, a standard first aid certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the workplace is any other workplace, other than a workplace in a wilderness area, and the ambulance response time for the workplace is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: less than twenty minutes, a basic first aid certificate, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: twenty minutes or more but not more than two hours, a standard first aid certificate; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the workplace is in a wilderness area, a standard first aid certificate and wilderness first aid training that is specially designed to meet the first aid needs of persons who work, live or travel in such an area.

Subsection.Text: A first aid attendant referred to in section 16.3 or paragraph 16.10(1)(a)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall be assigned to a first aid station or first aid room;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall be available to employees during working hours;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: shall render first aid to employees who are injured or ill at the workplace;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: shall, if required, accompany an injured or ill employee to a health unit or a medical treatment facility and render first aid in transit;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: shall, in providing care to an injured or ill employee, not be overruled by anyone not trained in first aid; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: shall be in charge of providing care for the injured or ill employee until the treatment is complete or the employee is under the care of an equally or more qualified caregiver.

Subsection.Text: The first aid attendant referred to in subsection (1)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: shall work close to the first aid station or first aid room to which the first aid attendant is assigned; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: shall not be assigned duties that will interfere with the prompt and adequate rendering of first aid.

Subsection.Text: At least one first aid station shall be provided for every workplace.
In multi-storey buildings, the location of first aid stations shall be such that employees are no more than two stories from a first aid station.
Every first aid station shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: located at or near the workplace;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: clearly identified by a conspicuous sign; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: accessible during all working hours.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall inspect every first aid station regularly, at least monthly, and shall ensure that its contents are maintained in a clean, dry and serviceable condition.
Subsection (1) does not apply if a first aid room, health unit or medical treatment facility that meets the requirements of subsection (3) is provided by the employer.
Subject to subsection (2), the employer shall post and keep posted or make available to every employee in a conspicuous place in each workplace

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: information regarding first aid to be rendered for any injury, occupational disease or illness;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: information regarding the location of first aid stations and first aid rooms;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: at every first aid station and first aid room, a list of first aid attendants, and information on how they may be located;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: near the telephones, a list of telephone numbers kept up-to-date for use in emergencies; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: information regarding transport procedures for injured employees.

Subsection.Text: At a remote workplace or in a motor vehicle, the information and lists referred to in subsection (1) shall be provided and retained with the first aid kit.

At every workplace with a number of employees set out in column 1 of an item of Schedule I to this Part, the employer shall ensure that there is provided a first aid kit of the type set out in column 2 of that item.

A first aid kit of type A, B, C or D shall contain the first aid supplies and equipment set out in column 1 of an item of Schedule II to this Part in the quantity, if any, set out in column 2 of that item for that type.

A first aid kit of type A for use in a remote workplace shall, in addition to the contents required by subsection (2), contain the first aid supplies and equipment set out in column 1 of an item of Schedule III to this Part in the quantity set out in column 2 of that item.
Prescription drugs or other medications not set out in Schedules II, III and IV to this Part shall not be stored in first aid kits or with first aid supplies.

Subject to subsection (2), if a hazard for skin or eye injury from a hazardous substance exists in the workplace, the employer shall ensure that shower facilities to wash the skin and eye wash facilities to irrigate the eyes are provided for immediate use by employees.
If it is not practicable to comply with subsection (1), the employer shall provide portable equipment that may be used in place of the facilities referred to in that subsection.

If, due to adverse or extreme weather conditions, it is not possible to comply with either subsection (1) or (2), the employer shall provide personal protection equipment for all employees likely to be exposed to the hazardous substance for all parts of their bodies that may be injured because of the presence of hazardous substances in the workplace.
If 200 or more employees are working at any time in a workplace, the employer shall ensure that a first aid room is provided and that it is clearly identified by a conspicuous sign.
A first aid room may be used for purposes other than first aid if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the minimum floor area required for first aid is maintained;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is no potential for delay in the administration of first aid; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the use for those other purposes will not impede the treatment of an injured employee or pose a hazard to employees.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply if a health unit or medical treatment facility at which medical treatment is provided without charge to employees is readily accessible.
Every first aid room provided in accordance with section 16.9 shall be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: under the supervision of a first aid attendant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: located as close as practicable to the workplace and within easy access to a toilet room;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: situated on a minimum floor area of 10 m2 and constructed to allow for optimum ease of access to persons carrying a patient on a stretcher;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: maintained in an orderly and sanitary condition; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: equipped with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a washbasin supplied with cold water and hot water that meets the standards set out in Part IX,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a storage cupboard and a counter,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a separate cubicle or curtained-off area with a cot or bed equipped with a moisture-protected mattress and two moisture-protected pillows,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a table and two or more chairs,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a telephone, or other effective means of communication, and an up-to-date list of appropriate emergency contacts and telephone numbers for use in emergencies, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the first aid supplies and equipment set out in Schedule IV to this Part.

Subsection.Text: In every first aid room referred to in subsection (1),

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the air shall be changed at least once each hour; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the temperature

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: shall be maintained at not less than 21oC, measured one meter above the floor, when the outdoor temperature is 21oC or less, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to the extent that is reasonably practicable, when the outdoor temperature in the shade exceeds 24oC, shall not exceed the outdoor temperature.

Section.Text: Before assigning employees to a workplace, the employer shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensure that for that workplace there is an ambulance service or other suitable means of transporting an injured or ill employee to a health unit or medical treatment facility; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide for that workplace a means of quickly summoning the ambulance service or other suitable means of transportation.

Subsection.Text: The courses for the basic first aid certificate and for the standard first aid certificate shall include the subjects set out in Schedule V.

Basic, standard and advanced first aid attendant training courses, including wilderness first aid courses, shall be given by a qualified person who holds a valid certification from an approved organization attesting that they are competent to deliver first aid training.

For advanced first aid, including wilderness first aid, the employer shall determine, in consultation with the workplace committee or the health and safety representative, the first aid training requirements for the workplace, having regard to the particular nature of the workplace.

The employer shall review the training program with respect to advanced first aid, including wilderness first aid, in consultation with the workplace committee or the health and safety representative at least once every three years and whenever there is a change of circumstances that may affect the content of the training.
Basic, standard and advanced first aid certificates, including wilderness first aid courses, are valid for a maximum of three years from the date of issue.
If first aid is required by this Part to be rendered, the first aid attendant who renders the first aid shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: enter in a first aid record the following information:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and time of the reporting of the injury or illness,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the full name of the injured or ill employee,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date, time and location of the occurrence of the injury or illness,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a brief description of the injury or illness,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: a brief description of the first aid rendered, if any,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: a brief description of arrangements made for the treatment or transportation of the injured or ill employee, and

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the names of witnesses, if applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: sign the first aid record beneath the information entered in accordance with paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: The information referred to in subsection (1) shall be entered

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if first aid was rendered to an employee at a remote workplace detached from the main party or on a snowmobile or other small vehicle, in the first aid record stored in the first aid kit at the site of the main party or work site; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in any other case, in the first aid record stored in the first aid kit.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall keep a first aid record containing information entered in accordance with subsection (2) for a period of two years beginning on the date of that entry.
Persons with access to first aid records shall keep the information contained in the records confidential, except as required for the purposes of meeting reporting obligations under Part XV.

On receiving a written request from a workers’ compensation authority for the province where the workplace is located or a medical practitioner, the employer shall provide an employee with a copy of the first aid record pertaining to the employee’s treatment.
The employer shall maintain a record of the expiry dates of the first aid certificates of the first aid attendants and make it available to them.

Paragraph.Label: (a)

Paragraph.Label: (c)

Heading.Label: PART XVII
Heading.TitleText: Safe Occupancy of the Work Place

Section.Text: In this Part, emergency evacuation plan means a written plan for use in an emergency, prepared in accordance with section 17.4.
This Part does not apply in respect of employees employed in the underground workings of mines.

Subsection.Text: Fire protection equipment shall be installed, inspected and maintained in every building in which there is a work place in accordance with the standards set out in Parts 6 and 7 of the National Fire Code.
All fire protection equipment shall be maintained and repaired by a qualified person.

Where more than 50 employees are working in a building at any time, the employer or employers of those employees shall prepare an emergency evacuation plan for all employees, including those who require special assistance, after consultation with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the work place committee or the health and safety representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the employers of any persons working in the building to whom the Act does not apply.

Subsection.Text: An emergency evacuation plan referred to in subsection (1) shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a plan of the building, showing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name, if any, and the address of the building,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of the owner of the building,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the names and locations of the tenants of the building,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of preparation of the plan,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the scale of the plan,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of the building in relation to nearby streets and in relation to all buildings and other structures located within 30 m of the building,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the maximum number of persons normally occupying the building at any time,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: a horizontal projection of the building, showing thereon its principal dimensions, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: the number of floors above and below ground level;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a plan of each floor of the building, showing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name, if any, and the address of the building,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of preparation of the plan,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the scale of the plan,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: a horizontal projection of the floor, showing thereon its principal dimensions,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: the number of the floor to which the plan applies,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: the maximum number of persons normally occupying the floor at any time,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of all fire escapes, fire exits, stairways, elevating devices, main corridors and other means of exit,

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of all fire protection equipment, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ix)
Subparagraph.Text: the location of the main electric power switches for the lighting system, elevating devices, principal heating, ventilation and air-conditioning equipment and other electrical equipment;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a full description of the evacuation procedures to be followed in evacuating the building, with the time required to complete the evacuation, including

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: activating the fire alarm,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: notifying the fire department, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: evacuating employees who require special assistance; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the names, room numbers and telephone numbers of the chief emergency warden and the deputy chief emergency warden of the building appointed by the employer or employers under section 17.7.

Subsection.Text: An emergency evacuation plan referred to in subsection (1) shall be kept up-to-date and shall take into account any changes in the building or the nature of its occupancy.
An employer referred to in subsection (1) shall keep a copy of the up-to-date emergency evacuation plan in the building to which it refers.

Every employer shall, after consultation with the work place committee or the health and safety representative and with the employers of any persons working in the building to whom the Act does not apply, prepare emergency procedures

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to be implemented if any person commits or threatens to commit an act that is likely to be hazardous to the health and safety of the employer or any of his or her employees;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if there is a possibility of an accumulation, spill or leak of a hazardous substance in a work place controlled by the employer, to be implemented in the event of such an accumulation, spill or leak;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if more than 50 employees are working in a building at any time, to be implemented when evacuation is not an appropriate means of ensuring the health and safety of employees;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: to be implemented in the event of a failure of the lighting system; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: to be implemented in the event of a fire.

Subsection.Text: The emergency procedures referred to in subsection (1) shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an emergency evacuation plan, where applicable, or a plan for evacuating employees who require special assistance to be implemented in the event of a fire;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a full description of the procedures to be followed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the emergency equipment provided by the employer; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a plan of the building, showing

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the name, if any, and the address of the building, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the name and address of the owner of the building.

Subsection.Text: The plan for the evacuation of employees who require special assistance shall be established in consultation with those employees.
Every employee shall be instructed and trained in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures to be followed by him in the event of an emergency; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the location, use and operation of fire protection equipment and emergency equipment provided by the employer.

Subsection.Text: Notices that set out the details of the evacuation plans and procedures referred to in paragraphs 17.4(2)(c) and 17.5(2)(a) and (b) shall be posted at locations accessible to every employee at the work place.
Where an employer or employers have prepared an emergency evacuation plan for a building, the employer or employers shall appoint

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a chief emergency warden and a deputy chief emergency warden for that building;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an emergency warden and a deputy emergency warden for each floor of the building that is occupied by employees of the employer or employers; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: monitors for any employee who require special assistance in evacuating the building.

Subsection.Text: The chief emergency warden and deputy chief emergency warden appointed for a building shall be employees who are normally employed in the building.

The emergency warden and the deputy emergency warden appointed for a floor in a building shall be employees who are normally employed on that floor and monitors for an employee who requires special assistance shall be employees who are normally employed on the same floor as the employee requiring special assistance.
Every emergency warden, deputy emergency warden and monitor appointed under section 17.7 shall be instructed and trained in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: his responsibilities under the emergency evacuation plan and the emergency procedures referred to in paragraph 17.5(1)(c); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the use of fire protection equipment.

Subsection.Text: A record of all instruction and training provided in accordance with subsection (1) shall be kept by the employer in the work place to which it applies for a period of two years from the date on which the instruction or training is provided.

In addition to the inspections carried out under section 17.3, a visual inspection of every building to which subsection 17.4(1) applies shall be carried out by a qualified person at least once every six months and shall include an inspection of all fire escapes, exits, stairways and fire protection equipment in the building in order to ensure that they are in serviceable condition and ready for use at all times.

A record of each inspection carried out in accordance with subsection (1) shall be dated and signed by the person who made the inspection and kept by the employer in the building to which it applies for a period of two years from the date on which it is signed.

Heading.TitleText: Meetings of Emergency Wardens and Drills

Subsection.Text: At least once every year and after any change is made in the emergency evacuation plan or the emergency procedures referred to in paragraph 17.5(1)(c) for a building,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: emergency wardens, deputy emergency wardens and monitors appointed under section 17.7 and employees requiring special assistance shall meet for the purpose of ensuring that they are familiar with the emergency evacuation plan and the emergency procedures and their responsibilities thereunder; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an evacuation or emergency drill shall be conducted for the employees in that building.

Subsection.Text: The employer or employers shall keep a record of each meeting and drill referred to in subsection (1) in the building referred to in that subsection for a period of two years from the date of the meeting or the drill.
The record referred to in subsection (2) shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of each meeting,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date of the meeting,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the names and titles of those present, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a summary of the matters discussed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in respect of each drill,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the date and time of the drill, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: where applicable, the length of time taken to evacuate the building.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall notify the local fire department for the building where an evacuation or emergency drill is to take place at least 24 hours in advance of the date and time of the drill.
Subject to subsection (2), no person shall, in a fire hazard area,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: use any equipment, machinery or tool of a type that may provide a source of ignition; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: smoke or use an open flame or other source of ignition.

Subsection.Text: Where it is not reasonably practicable to avoid performing work involving the use of any equipment, machinery or tool that may provide a source of ignition in an area that has an atmosphere that contains or is likely to contain explosive concentrations of combustible dust or in an area where combustible dust has accumulated in a sufficient quantity to be a fire hazard, the following shall apply:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the atmosphere and surfaces in the area where the work is to be performed and within that portion of the surrounding area that is accessible to sparks or pieces of hot metal produced by the work shall be substantially free of combustible dust;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: where any equipment, machinery or tool produces combustible dust that may reach the areas referred to in paragraph (a), the equipment, machinery or tool shall be made inoperative prior to and during the time the work is being performed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in so far as is practicable, the area where the work is to be performed shall be enclosed to prevent the escape of sparks or pieces of hot metal produced by the work;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all openings in floors and walls through which sparks or pieces of hot metal produced by the work may pass shall be sealed or covered to prevent such passage;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any combustible materials within the areas referred to in paragraph (a) shall be removed or, if this is not reasonably practicable, shall be covered with a non-combustible protective covering;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: floors and walls of combustible material within the areas referred to in paragraph (a) shall be protected from the fire hazard by

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: drenching the surfaces of the floors and walls with water, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: covering the floors and walls with a non-combustible protective covering;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the work shall be performed under the supervision of a qualified person, who shall remain in the work area while the work is performed and for 30 minutes thereafter; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: there shall be readily available in the work area at least one hand-held portable fire extinguisher and

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a water hose at least 25 mm in diameter that is connected to a water supply line, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a supply of not less than 200 L of water and a bucket.

Section.Text: Signs shall be posted in conspicuous places at all entrances to a fire hazard area

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: identifying the area as a fire hazard area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prohibiting the use of an open flame or other source of ignition in the area.

Section.Text: The definitions in this section apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: contaminated environment means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a point of discharge of effluent from a sewer, a water or sewage treatment plant or an industrial plant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a site where chemical or biological effluent has accumulated; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the site of an oil or radioactive spill. (environnement contaminé)

Definition.Text: decompression table means a table or set of tables that shows a schedule of rates for the safe ascent of a diver from depth in order to minimize the risk of decompression sickness. (table de décompression)

dive supervisor means a qualified person who has been designated by the employer to be in charge of a diving operation at the dive site, including the health and safety of its divers. (chef de plongée)
diver means a qualified person who performs work under water. (plongeur)

diver’s flag means the rectangular red flag set out in Schedule I, each side of which is not less than 50 cm in length, that has a white diagonal stripe extending from the tip of the hoist to the bottom of the flag. (pavillon du plongeur)
diver’s tender means a qualified person who attends to a diver for the duration of a dive. (assistant du plongeur)
hyperbaric chamber means a pressure vessel and associated equipment designed to subject humans to greater-than-atmospheric pressures. (caisson hyperbare)
International Code Flag A means the white and dark blue flag set out in Schedule II, which is not less than 1 m in height. (pavillon A du code international)
liveboating means the support of a diving operation from a vessel that is not at anchor, made fast to the shore or a fixed structure, or aground. (plongée avec bateau-soutien)
no-decompression limit means the maximum time that can be spent at a depth without requiring a decompression stop. (limite de remontée sans palier)
surface supply dive means a diving operation where a diver is supplied with breathing mixtures by a life support umbilical from the surface. (plongée non autonome)
therapeutic recompression means the treatment of a diver in a hyperbaric chamber in accordance with generally accepted tables and practices. (recompression thérapeutique)
type 1 dives means diving operations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the primary purpose of which is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to conduct scientific, archaeological or other research operations, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to gather evidence or information relating to a crime;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: do not require decompression,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: do not involve diving in the vicinity of underwater pressure differentials,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: are not related to the search, construction, repair or inspection of ships, bridge piers, wharves, dry docks, underwater tunnels, or water control and water intake facilities, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: do not involve using underwater welding or cutting equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the depth of which does not exceed 40 m. (plongées de type 1)

Definition.Text: type 2 dives means diving operations other than type 1 dives. (plongées de type 2)

Section.Text: This Part does not apply to diving operations to which the Canada Oil and Gas Diving Regulations, the Nova Scotia Offshore Area Petroleum Diving Regulations or the Newfoundland Offshore Area Petroleum Diving Regulations apply.

Subsection.Text: Division I applies to type 1 dives and type 2 dives.
Division II applies to type 2 dives.

Every employer shall establish written procedures and requirements that are to be followed and met by employees involved in diving operations and that specify which of those procedures and requirements

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: apply to each type of dive in which the employees are likely to engage, including the qualifications of the dive team members;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are to be implemented or met to counter any known hazards, including those arising out of contaminated or potentially contaminated environments, low visibility, hazardous water flow conditions and entrapment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: deal with emergency situations and the evacuation of dive team members.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall review the procedures referred to in paragraph (1)(c) at least once a year and, if necessary, revise those procedures.
The procedures and requirements referred to in subsection (1) shall be available to all employees involved in diving operations.
Every employer shall ensure that an employee required to dive has received instruction and training with respect to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the types of dives in which the employee is likely to participate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the equipment that the employee is likely to use.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall ensure that an employee involved in diving operations demonstrates on an annual basis that the employee is competent to perform the types of dives in which the employee is likely to participate.
Every employer shall ensure that persons who are not employees and who dive with employees demonstrate that they are competent to perform the types of dives in which they will participate.

Every employer shall ensure that an employee required to dive has been trained in first aid and cardio-pulmonary resuscitation and in the recognition of the symptoms and the management of diving-related injuries.
Where oxygen equipment for therapeutic purposes is provided at the dive site, the employer shall ensure that an employee required to dive or act as a diver’s tender is trained in its use.
Every employer shall ensure that an employee required to dive has

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: received a medical examination within the last two years; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: been declared fit to dive, or fit to dive with specified restrictions, by the examining physician.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the examining physician shall use as a guideline the factors and tests listed in Appendices A and B of CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z275.2-92, Occupational Safety Code for Diving Operations, published in English in April 1992 and in French in February 1994, as amended from time to time.

Where the physician examining the employee pursuant to subsection (1) declares the employee fit to dive with specified restrictions, the employer shall not permit the employee to dive otherwise than in accordance with the specified restrictions.
Every employer shall ensure that a diver who has been treated for a pressure-related injury or illness does not dive unless written clearance for further diving is given by a physician.
If a diver considers himself or herself unfit to dive owing to illness, fatigue or any other cause, the diver shall inform the employer of that fact.
An employer who has been notified pursuant to subsection (1) shall not permit the employee to dive.

Every employer shall ensure that, for each dive, the dive team develops a dive plan that identifies the surface and underwater conditions and hazards likely to be encountered, including those arising from contaminated environments and underwater pressure differentials, and that specifies

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the duties of each dive team member;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the diving equipment to be used;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the breathing supply requirements, including the reserve supply;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the thermal protection to be used;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the repetitive dive factor;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the no-decompression limit;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency procedures to be followed;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the communication methods to be used;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: for a type 1 dive that is a scuba dive, whether there is a need for a diver’s tender;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the circumstances in which the dive must be terminated;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures to be followed to ensure that machinery, equipment or devices that could create a hazard have been locked out; and

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: whether lifelines must be used.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a type 1 dive, the dive plan referred to in subsection (1) shall also specify whether there is a need for a standby diver.
In the case of a type 2 dive that requires decompression, the dive plan referred to in subsection (1) shall also specify the decompression schedule to be used.
Subject to subsections (3) and (4) and Division II, every employer shall ensure that a dive team consisting of at least two divers is present at every dive site.
One member of the dive team referred to in subsection (1) shall be designated as the dive supervisor.
A diver’s tender shall be present at any surface supply dive.
A dive boat operator shall be present at any dive carried out from a boat or vessel.

Section.Text: Every employer shall ensure that, for the duration of a surface supply dive, the diver’s tender devotes his or her entire time and attention to the work of a diver’s tender.

Every employer shall ensure that, for the duration of a type 2 dive carried out from a boat or vessel, the dive boat operator devotes his or her entire time and attention to the work as a dive boat operator.
A standby diver shall be present at all times when type 2 dives are in progress.
Where a standby diver is needed pursuant to subsection 18.9(2) or section 18.13, the standby diver shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be trained and equipped to operate at the depth at which and in the circumstances in which a submerged diver is operating;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be readily available to assist the submerged diver in the event of an emergency; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: not dive or be required to dive except in an emergency.

Section.Text: Every employer shall, for the purposes of paragraph 18.9(1)(g), arrange for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: assistance in the event of an emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: medical support on a 24-hour-a-day basis and a suitable means of communication between the dive site and that medical support; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: evacuation of a diver to a hyperbaric chamber if necessary.

Section.Text: Every employer shall ensure that, when a diver shows any indication of a pressure-related injury or requires therapeutic recompression,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the necessary first-aid treatment is initiated; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the medical support referred to in paragraph 18.15(b) is notified immediately.

Section.Text: Diving operations, repetitive dives and the treatment of divers shall be carried out in accordance with generally accepted decompression tables and procedures.
Every employer shall ensure that the following flags are conspicuously displayed at or in close proximity to the dive site whenever diving operations are conducted in areas of marine traffic:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the International Code Flag A, hoisted from any vessel, boat or platform used in support of a dive in such a manner as to ensure all-round visibility of the dive site; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one or more diver’s flags from a white buoy which may be equipped with

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a light, in which case the light shall be yellow and flashing, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: reflecting material, in which case the reflecting material shall be yellow.

Section.Text: Every diving operation shall be conducted under the supervision of a dive supervisor.
The primary duties of the dive supervisor shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: ensuring that every member of the dive team is familiar with the dive plan;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: ensuring that every member of the dive team understands the member’s duties, including the emergency procedures to be followed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: ensuring, before each dive, that all necessary equipment is available and in good operating condition; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: supervising the entire diving operation.

Section.Text: Immediately before each dive, the dive supervisor shall review the nature of any hazards at the dive site and ensure that all divers are fully aware of the hazards likely to be encountered in the diving operation.
Every employer shall, for the purposes of paragraph 18.9(1)(h), ensure that all means of communication used at the dive site are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: appropriate for the operation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: understood by all members of the dive team.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall ensure that a reserve breathing supply sufficient to allow the safe termination of a dive is immediately available to the diver.
Where required by the dive plan, the reserve breathing supply referred to in subsection (1) shall be carried by the diver.

Section.Text: Every employer shall ensure that air compressors and filter systems are tested annually and produce breathing mixtures that meet the requirements of clause 3.8 of CSA Standard CAN/CSA-Z275.2-92, Occupational Safety Code for Diving Operations, published in English in April 1992 and in French in February 1994, as amended from time to time.
Where a dive plan requires that oxygen for therapeutic purposes be available, the employer shall supply

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: demand-type oxygen therapy equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an adequate quantity of oxygen.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall ensure that all diving equipment used by employees is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designed for its intended use and maintained in a condition that ensures its continuing operation for the purpose and at the depth for which it was designed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: inspected, tested, maintained and calibrated by a qualified person at intervals recommended by the manufacturer and whenever the equipment is thought to be defective.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall ensure that diving equipment used by persons who are not employees and who are granted access to the work place is in a condition that ensures its operation for the purpose and at the depth for which it was designed.
Immediately before each dive, every diver shall check that all the equipment the diver requires is present, properly fastened in place and functioning.
Before beginning a descent, every diver shall conduct the check specified in subsection (1) again in the water.

Every employer shall ensure that whenever diving operations are carried out from a diving station located more than 2 m above the water, the divers are transported through the air-water interface by a cage, basket or platform.

Every employer shall ensure that a stationary platform from which a diver works, or any cage, basket or platform on or in which a diver is lowered to or raised from an underwater work place, and any associated hoisting devices and tackle,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are used for the purpose for which they were designed; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: do not in themselves create a hazard.

Subsection.Text: Any cage, basket or platform and any associated equipment referred to in subsection (2) shall be dedicated to the diving operations until the dive is completed.

Section.Text: Floating equipment used in diving operations, including a vessel that is anchored or moored, shall not be moved or relocated while a diver is in the water unless the dive supervisor agrees to the move or relocation.
The employer shall ensure that, when a floating platform, vessel or boat is used in support of the dive, it remains on site at all times while a diver is in the water.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall ensure that, where a dive plan requires the use of a lifeline to tether a diver, the lifeline

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is free of knots and splices, other than knots and splices necessary to attach the lifeline to the diver and the dive site;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: has a breaking strength of not less than 1400 kg;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is secured to the diver so as to prevent loss of contact with the diver; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: is secured at the surface to a safe point of anchorage.

Subsection.Text: A lifeline shall always be used in dives taking place under ice.
Every employer shall ensure that a lifeline is tended at all times by a diver’s tender.

Section.Text: Every submersible pressure gauge and every depth gauge shall be inspected by a qualified person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: before being used for the first time;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: thereafter at intervals not exceeding 12 months; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whenever the gauge is thought to be defective.

Subsection.Text: Where an employee finds a defect in any diving equipment, including pressure gauges and depth gauges, that may render it unsafe for use, the employee shall immediately report the defect to the employer.

An employer shall mark or tag as unsafe and remove from service any diving equipment, including pressure gauges and depth gauges, that may be used by employees where a defect may render it unsafe for use.

Section.Text: A dive shall be terminated in accordance with the dive plan referred to in subsection 18.9(1) or when

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a dive team member requests termination;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a diver loses contact with or fails to respond correctly to a communication from a diving partner;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a diver loses contact with or fails to respond correctly to a communication from the diver’s tender;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a diver’s primary breathing supply fails; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a diver becomes aware of any sign of a malfunction of equipment or any sign or symptom of diver distress.

Section.Text: Every employer shall ensure that, on completion of a dive, a diver remains under observation for a period of time sufficient to ensure the health and safety of the diver.

Subsection.Text: An employer shall not allow a diver to fly at an altitude greater than 300 m above the altitude of the dive site unless the following period of time has elapsed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 12 hours following a no-decompression dive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 24 hours following a decompression dive; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: such time as is specified by a physician who treated the diver for a pressure-related injury.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to an emergency air evacuation.

In the event of an emergency air evacuation, provision shall be made to furnish the diver with oxygen, and the flight altitude and in-flight conditions shall be those recommended by the attending physician or dive supervisor.
Every diver shall report to the employer any occurrence that has caused a diving-related injury to the diver.
The employer shall investigate the occurrence reported pursuant to subsection (1) and keep a written record of its findings.
Every employer shall ensure that a dive record is kept and maintained for every diver.
The record referred to in subsection (1) shall contain, for each dive,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the dive;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the dive location;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the diver;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the standby diver, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the diver’s tender, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the signature of the diver and the dive supervisor; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the breathing mixture used, if other than air.

Subsection.Text: The record referred to in subsection (1) shall also contain, for each type 1 dive,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the total elapsed time, measured in minutes, from the time the diver leaves the surface to the time the diver begins final ascent, rounded to the next whole minute;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum depth reached; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any unusual incident or condition, including emergency decompression time.

Subsection.Text: The record referred to in subsection (1) shall also contain, for each type 2 dive,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the type of diving equipment used;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the time the diver leaves the surface;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum depth reached;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the time the diver begins final ascent;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the time the diver reaches the surface;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the decompression schedule used, if any; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any unusual incident or condition.

Subsection.Text: The employer shall keep the record referred to in subsection (1) for a period of 12 months after the date of the dive.
Every employer shall keep a dated dive record for each diver that shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the year in which the dive occurs;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the maximum depth reached;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the total elapsed time, measured in minutes, from the time the diver leaves the surface to the time the diver begins final ascent, rounded to the next whole minute;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the breathing mixture used, if other than air;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any unusual incident or condition;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: any occurrence reported pursuant to subsection 18.37(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of any record referred to in subsection 18.37(2).

Subsection.Text: The employer shall annually supply the record referred to in subsection (1) to the diver and keep a copy for a period of five years after the date on which the diver ceases to be employed by the employer.

Section.Text: Every employer shall keep a record of all diver instruction and training received and all competency demonstrations given pursuant to section 18.5, for as long as the employee is employed by the employer as a diver.
Every employer shall maintain a record of each air quality test performed pursuant to section 18.24 for a period of five years after the date on which the test was made.

Every employer shall maintain a record of each equipment inspection, test, maintenance and calibration performed pursuant to paragraph 18.26(1)(b) for a period of five years after the date on which the inspection, test, maintenance or calibration was performed.

Heading.TitleText: Approach to Water Control and Intake Facilities

Section.Text: Underwater approaches to water control and intake facilities where underwater pressure differentials may be encountered shall be made in accordance with sections 18.44 to 18.46.
Every employer shall ensure that a diver working near a facility referred to in section 18.43 wears a lifeline tended from a position outside the approach area.

Every employer shall ensure that any diver required to approach an underwater intake pipe, tunnel or duct is provided with the means to differentiate the intake from any other similar intake in the dive area.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), every employer shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a diver is not allowed to approach any underwater intake or structure where underwater pressure differentials may be encountered until the flow of water is stopped or controlled; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the flow of water is not re-established until the diver leaves the water or until the dive supervisor has determined that the diver is clear of the approach area referred to in paragraph (a).

Subsection.Text: Where the flow of water referred to in subsection (1) cannot be stopped, the employer shall assess the safety of a diver approaching the intake by determining flow patterns using reliable indicators, direct measurements or calculations.

Section.Text: No employer shall permit a diver to approach a work place that may be hazardous because of the operation of machinery or equipment, unless the machinery or equipment is secured against inadvertent movement and made inoperable for the duration of the dive.
Where there is a likelihood that a diver may be entrapped, the employer shall ensure that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a two-way voice communication system between the diver and the diver’s tender is provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a second dive team, equipped to rescue a diver in the event of an emergency, is present at the dive site.

Subsection.Text: The initiation of underwater explosive charges at a dive site shall be under the direct control of the dive supervisor.
A two-way voice communication system shall be provided when explosives are being used at a dive site, unless the voice communication system itself would pose a hazard.

Section.Text: Every employer shall ensure that a hyperbaric chamber meeting the requirements of CSA Standard CAN/CSA Z275.1-93, Hyperbaric Facilities, published in English in December 1993 and in French in January 1995, as amended from time to time, for Class A (double-lock type) hyperbaric chambers, is available and in operable condition whenever

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a decompression dive is occurring; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the depth of a dive is to exceed 40 m.

Section.Text: Every employer shall ensure that a hyperbaric chamber is operated by a qualified person.

Subsection.Text: Every employer shall ensure that a second source of power capable of supplying sufficient power to operate all essential diving equipment is available in the event of failure of the primary power source.
Every employer shall ensure that the second source of power referred to in subsection (1) is capable of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: being rapidly brought on line; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: operating all equipment essential to the diving operation.

Section.Text: Sections 18.54 to 18.62 apply to surface supply type 2 dives.
Where the planned depth of a dive does not exceed 40 m, there shall be at least three persons present at the dive site, of whom

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least two are divers, one of whom is a standby diver; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at least one is a diver’s tender.

Section.Text: The diver’s tender or the standby diver of a diving operation, the depth of which does not exceed 40 m, shall be designated as the dive supervisor.
Where the planned depth of a dive exceeds 40 m, there shall be at least four persons at the dive site, of whom

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: at least two are divers, one of whom is a standby diver;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one is the dive supervisor; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: one is the diver’s tender.

Section.Text: Every employer shall ensure that, except in an emergency, each surface supply diver in the water has a separate diver’s tender.

Subsection.Text: The voice communication system provided between a diver and the surface shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: allow the diver’s breathing to be heard at the surface; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: include a recording system where the maximum depth of the dive is greater than 55 m.

Subsection.Text: An emergency signal system must be in effect during a diving operation to supplement the primary communication system.

Section.Text: A reserve breathing supply appropriate for the dive shall be carried by each diver.
Every employer shall ensure that nonreturn valves are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: fitted to all diving helmets and surface supply diving masks; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: checked daily before the commencement of diving operations in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations.

Section.Text: Every employer shall ensure that every life support umbilical incorporates a lifeline rigged to prevent stress on the air line.
Every employer shall ensure that, in a liveboating operation,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a method that will prevent the lifeline or life support umbilical from becoming entangled in the propellers is used;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the diver’s tender is a qualified person for the type of tending used; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel operator is a qualified person.

Section.Text: Sections 18.64 to 18.67 apply to type 2 dives in the course of which divers use scuba.
In a diving operation where the diver is tethered to the surface by a lifeline or float, there shall be at least three persons present at the dive site, of whom

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one is a standby diver; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one is a diver’s tender.

Section.Text: In a diving operation where the diver is not tethered to the surface by a lifeline or float, there shall be a through-water, two-way voice communication system between the divers and between the divers and the surface, and at least four persons present at the dive site, of whom

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: three are divers, one of whom is a standby diver; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one is a diver’s tender.

Section.Text: One of the employees on the surface shall be designated as the dive supervisor of the scuba diving operation.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), dives shall be limited to a depth not exceeding 40 m.
A diver may dive to a depth greater than 40 m for the purpose of saving a life provided that, where conditions permit, the diver is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: secured by a lifeline; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: tended by a diver’s tender.
